cheatsheetvideos.quote: Karla only needed to Study for 1 hour. She then went to the DMV and Passed her test
DMV Test Cheat Sheet: John Tells us How to Ace The Driver’s Test On your First Try

questions.question: A five-ounce glass of wine contains the same amount of alcohol as:
questions.answerB: One 12-ounce can of beer.
questions.answerC: A gallon of wine.
questions.explanation: A five-ounce glass of wine (12 percent alcohol), a 12-ounce can or bottle of beer, and 1.5 ounces of 86-proof liquor all contain approximately the same amount of alcohol. A person's ability to drive will be equally impaired by the same amount of alcohol no matter what kind of alcoholic beverage they drink.

questions.question: If you plan to pass another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Not assume the other driver will make space for you to return to your lane.
questions.answerB: Assume the other driver will let you pass if you use your turn signal.
questions.answerC: Assume the other driver will maintain a constant speed.
questions.explanation: Even when you signal, you should not assume that the space you want to occupy is free or that other drivers will give you the right-of-way.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerB: Begin signaling as you move into the next lane.
questions.answerC: Signal at least 500 feet before your lane change when driving on residential streets.
questions.explanation: Other cars and motorcycles are often hidden in a vehicle’s blind spot, so be sure to glance over your shoulder before you begin a lane change. Begin signaling 100 feet before changing lanes or turning in a residential area. Signal five seconds in advance when changing lanes on a freeway.

questions.question: A solid white line on the right edge of the highway slants in to the left. That shows that:
questions.answerA: There is an intersection just ahead.
questions.answerB: You are approaching a construction area.
questions.answerC: You will be required to turn left just ahead.
questions.explanation: A solid line along the side of the road indicates where its edge is, marking the boundary between the travel lane and the shoulder. If the edge line angles toward the center of the road, this means that the road is narrower ahead.

questions.question: Minimum speed signs are designed to:
questions.answerB: Show current local road conditions.
questions.answerC: Test future traffic signal needs.
questions.explanation: To keep a smooth traffic flow, some highways have minimum speed limits. If you drive more slowly than the minimum speed limit, you can halt the traffic flow and create dangerous conditions. Even if there is no posted minimum speed limit, those driving too slowly can be dangerous and may receive a citation.

questions.question: The best way to avoid hydroplaning is to:
questions.answerB: Slow down when roads are wet or slushy.
questions.answerC: Watch out for standing water or puddles.
questions.explanation: When roads are wet, cars take a longer distance to stop and may skid on quick turns. Do not use cruise control when driving under wet or icy conditions. Reduce your speed and drive with caution.

questions.question: If you see an edge line that angles inward on a road, it means:
questions.answerB: The road is narrowing.
questions.answerC: The road is getting wider.
questions.explanation: If you see an edge line that angles inward on a road, it means the road ahead is becoming narrower. Be sure to merge safely.

questions.question: Vehicle stopping distances never depend on:
questions.answerB: The time of day.
questions.answerC: The condition of your vehicle's brakes.
questions.answerD: The condition and type of your vehicle's tires.
questions.explanation: The distance that a vehicle needs to stop depends on the motorist's reaction time, weather and visibility conditions, the vehicle's weight, the conditions of the vehicle's brakes, the condition and type of the vehicle's tires, roadway conditions, and speed.

questions.question: What should you be most concerned about when you see this sign?
questions.answerA: Driving with your headlights out of alignment because one side of your car is higher than the other.
questions.answerB: Damaging a tire from drifting onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Hydroplaning, if the shoulder has water on it.
questions.answerD: Losing control of the vehicle if you drift onto the shoulder.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the shoulder is lower than the road in the area ahead. If you drift off of the roadway and one wheel drops onto a low shoulder, do not slam on the brakes or steer sharply to try to get back onto the roadway. This could easily cause you to lose control of your vehicle.

questions.question: You want to back out of your driveway. You see children playing nearby. Before you start to move your car, you should:
questions.answerA: Rev your engine to warn the children that you are moving.
questions.answerB: Sound your horn so the children will hear you.
questions.answerC: Walk to the back of the car to be sure the way is clear.
questions.answerD: Tell the children to stay away from the driveway.
questions.explanation: When you back up a vehicle, look through your back window for pedestrians and other obstacles. Do not rely only on your mirrors, especially when children are near. Before you back into or out of a driveway, get out of the vehicle and check behind your vehicle.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Lane ends or roadway narrows ahead.
questions.answerC: Industrial area.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign warns drivers that the right lane is ending or that the road is narrowing ahead.

questions.question: On a New York State highway where there is no posted speed limit, the fastest you may legally drive is:
questions.answerB: 55 mph.
questions.answerC: 60 mph.
questions.explanation: If no maximum speed limit is posted on a state highway, the fastest someone may legally drive is 55 mph.

questions.question: Assuming that the street is level, what should you do after you have finished parallel parking in a space between two other cars?
questions.answerA: Leave your front wheels turned toward the curb.
questions.answerB: Make sure your car almost touches the car behind you.
questions.answerC: Move as far forward in the space as possible.
questions.answerD: Straighten your front wheels and leave room between cars.
questions.explanation: The final step of parallel parking (unless you are on a hill) is to bring your wheels straight and pull forward, allowing room for surrounding vehicles to maneuver safely.

questions.question: What kinds of drugs can affect your driving ability?
questions.answerB: Marijuana
questions.answerC: Cold remedies
questions.explanation: Many kinds of drugs can impair your ability to drive. This includes illegal drugs and legal prescription or over-the-counter medications. It can be a criminal offense to drive while impaired by any drug.

questions.question: To improve visibility lowered by rain or fog, drivers should use their:
questions.answerB: High beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Parking lights.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights should be used when driving in rainy or foggy weather. Even if they do little to help you see, low beams will make it easier for others to see you.

questions.question: Blind persons legally have the right-of-way when crossing the street when they are:
questions.answerB: Led by a guide dog or using a white or metallic cane.
questions.answerC: Helped by another person.
questions.explanation: Blind pedestrians who are being led by a guide dog or are using a white or metallic cane have the right-of-way at a marked or unmarked crosswalk, even if the traffic signals or other right-of-way rules are not in their favor.

questions.question: This sign is a:
questions.answerB: Regulatory sign.
questions.answerC: Warning sign.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. There may be an upcoming change in traffic direction, a steep downgrade, or another potentially hazardous situation that requires action on the part of the driver.

questions.question: Blind spots are:
questions.answerA: Spots in your vision when you become fatigued.
questions.answerB: Areas of the road that cannot be seen in a vehicle's mirrors.
questions.answerC: Traffic control devices.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, look over your shoulder in the direction you plan to move. Check for obstructions near the rear corners of your vehicle. These areas are called “blind spots” because you cannot see them by using your mirrors.

questions.question: In the state of New York, ____ must wear seat belts in moving vehicles.
questions.answerB: Only passengers
questions.answerC: Drivers and all passengers
questions.explanation: In the state of New York, all adults in moving motor vehicles are required to use seat belts. All children in moving vehicles should be properly fastened into seat belts, booster seats, or child restraint systems. Drivers or passengers may be charged fines of up to $100 for failing to properly use seat belts.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Hill ahead.
questions.answerC: Truck stop ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign indicates that there is a steep hill ahead. Slow down and be ready to shift to a lower gear to control your speed and protect your brakes from damage.

questions.question: A fully loaded tractor-trailer traveling at 55 mph could take up to ____ to come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: 125 feet
questions.answerC: 400 feet
questions.explanation: Tractor-trailers take longer distances to stop than smaller cars traveling at the same speed. A fully loaded tractor-trailer may take almost 400 feet to come to a complete stop when driving at 55 mph.

questions.question: This symbol is used for:
questions.answerB: Slow-moving vehicles.
questions.answerC: Yield signs.
questions.explanation: A reflective orange triangle on the rear of a vehicle means it travels only at slow speeds. You may see this sign on roadwork equipment, farm vehicles, or horse-drawn wagons and carriages. It appears as a solid orange triangle during the day and a hollow red triangle at night.

questions.question: Allow extra space in front of your vehicle when following a:
questions.answerB: Passenger vehicle.
questions.answerC: Motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Allow for extra space when driving behind a motorcycle. Motorcycles can stop more quickly than other vehicles can and you must have adequate room to stop if the motorcyclist brakes or falls off. Also, remember that motorcycles are difficult to see at night because they only have one tail light.

questions.question: When entering the interstate, check for a gap in traffic in the nearest lane, adjust your speed to match traffic, signal, and:
questions.answerA: Expect traffic to allow you to proceed into the lane, since you have the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Merge carefully into the gap.
questions.answerC: Wait for the lane to clear before merging.
questions.explanation: Before merging into interstate traffic, you should identify a gap, accelerate to the speed of traffic, and signal. Merge into the gap when it is safe to do so. Be alert to other traffic and do not expect other drivers to clear the lane.

questions.question: The car behind you begins to pass you. You should:
questions.answerA: Maintain your speed so traffic will flow smoothly.
questions.answerB: Pull to the right and stop so it can pass.
questions.answerC: Slow down slightly and stay in your lane.
questions.answerD: Blow your horn to signal that it to pass.
questions.explanation: If another vehicle passes you on the left, decrease your speed slightly and keep to the right. When the vehicle has safely passed and is ahead of you, resume your normal speed.

questions.question: People driving under the influence of alcohol are:
questions.answerA: Not a problem in New York State.
questions.answerB: Every driver's problem.
questions.answerC: A police enforcement problem only.
questions.answerD: Only a problem to those who drink.
questions.explanation: Every impaired or intoxicated driver is dangerous, both to themselves and to others on the road.

questions.question: When two vehicles enter an intersection from different highways at the same time, which vehicle must yield the right-of-way?
questions.answerB: The vehicle on the left
questions.answerC: The vehicle on the right
questions.explanation: At intersections that are controlled by signs or signals and at intersections that are uncontrolled, the driver on the left must yield the right-of-way to the driver on the right when two vehicles arrive to the intersection at the same time.

questions.question: Sudden wind gusts on highways:
questions.answerA: Generally affect only the movement of large vehicles.
questions.answerB: Only cause visibility problems.
questions.answerC: Can cause problems for all vehicles.
questions.explanation: While it can create special problems for large vehicles, strong wind can cause problems for all drivers. Wind can lower visibility by blowing dirt and dust into the roadway, but it can sometimes also physically move a vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following are used on some highways to direct drivers into the proper lanes for turning?
questions.answerB: Flashing yellow lights
questions.answerC: White lines on the side of the road
questions.answerD: White arrows in the middle of the lanes
questions.explanation: Arrows may be used to indicate which lanes should be used for specific purposes, such as driving straight or making a turn.

questions.question: If you come to a railroad crossing with lowered gates and flashing warning lights, you should:
questions.answerA: Drive around the crossing gates if you can't see a train.
questions.answerB: Come to a complete stop well behind the gates, wait for the tracks to clear, and proceed once the gates are lifted.
questions.answerC: Slow down and drive around the gates.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing where signs, warning devices, or flaggers warn you of the presence of a train. It is illegal to drive around lowered gates.

questions.question: When you see this sign, you:
questions.answerA: Are approaching a railroad crossing and should prepare to stop.
questions.answerB: Will always stop at the upcoming railroad crossing.
questions.answerC: Should stop and wait for a signal before crossing the railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that you are approaching a railroad crossing. You must look, listen, slow down, and prepare to stop. Wait for any trains to pass before you proceed.

questions.question: Which of these statements is true about large trucks?
questions.answerA: They take longer to stop than passenger vehicles.
questions.answerB: They all have air brakes that allow them to stop quickly.
questions.answerC: They are more maneuverable than passenger vehicles.
questions.explanation: Large trucks take longer to stop than other vehicles traveling at the same speed. The average passenger vehicle traveling at 55 mph can stop within 400 feet. However, a large truck traveling at the same speed can take almost 800 feet to stop.

questions.question: An inattentive driver is a driver who:
questions.answerA: Stares at objects off the roadway or daydreams while driving.
questions.answerB: Maintains eye contact during a conversation with a passenger while driving.
questions.answerC: Only watches the vehicle ahead of their vehicle.
questions.explanation: Do not become distracted by looking at passengers, attempting to find something in your vehicle, looking at reading material, sightseeing, or daydreaming while driving. Continue scanning the road, checking your mirrors, and looking at the instrument panel at regular intervals. Developing these safe habits will keep you attentive as a driver.

questions.question: You may cross a single solid white line on the highway:
questions.answerB: If traffic conditions require you to do so.
questions.answerC: Only to turn into a driveway.
questions.explanation: You may cross a single solid line to pass other vehicles or change lanes, but only if obstructions on the road or in traffic make the lane change necessary.

questions.question: You are coming to an intersection and have a green light. Pedestrians are crossing against the red. You should:
questions.answerB: Speed up and pass in front of the pedestrians.
questions.answerC: Stop to let the pedestrians cross safely.
questions.answerD: Drive close to the pedestrians and frighten them so they’ll think twice before crossing against a red light.
questions.explanation: Yield to pedestrians and cars that may be caught in an intersection when you have a green light. Be careful around pedestrians under every circumstance.

questions.question: Which of the following does alcohol affect?
questions.answerB: Reaction time
questions.answerC: Judgement of distances
questions.explanation: Alcohol reduces reaction time, reduces your ability to see clearly, changes your judgment of speed and distances, often makes you less inhibited, and makes you more prone to take chances. It is especially dangerous to drink and drive after dark because alcohol reduces your ability to recover from the glare of headlights.

questions.question: A chemical test is used to measure:
questions.answerB: Blood alcohol content.
questions.answerC: Vision.
questions.explanation: Blood alcohol content (BAC) is normally determined by a chemical test of breath, blood, urine, or saliva. However, a chemical test is not necessary to prove that you were intoxicated or impaired. The testimony of a police officer about how you were driving, or your appearance and behavior when arrested, can provide enough evidence to convict you, even without a chemical test.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Don't drink if you are going to drive.
questions.answerB: Slippery when wet.
questions.answerC: Road curves ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that the road is slippery when wet.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Slow down if an emergency vehicle is approaching.
questions.answerB: Look both ways as you cross the intersection.
questions.answerC: Always come to a full stop at the intersection.
questions.answerD: Slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.
questions.explanation: Decrease your speed as you approach an intersection with a yield sign. Prepare to stop and yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians in the intersection or crossroad. You must come to a full stop at a yield sign if traffic conditions require it.

questions.question: Continuous hard braking on ice and snow often:
questions.answerB: Locks the front wheels of a vehicle, causing a loss of steering.
questions.answerC: Keeps the brakes from freezing.
questions.explanation: Continuous hard braking on snow and ice can result in the locking of the front brake, causing a loss of steering. To avoid the need for excessive braking, make sure to maintain an appropriate speed for conditions.

questions.question: Night driving can be more difficult than driving during the day because:
questions.answerA: Cars overheat more quickly at night.
questions.answerB: Visibility is reduced in the dark.
questions.answerC: It is more likely to be raining at night.
questions.answerD: You are more likely to encounter a motorcycle at night.
questions.explanation: At night, your field of vision is reduced. To make sure you are able to react to hazards on the roadway, always use appropriate headlights. Drive slowly enough that you are able to stop within the distance that you can see ahead.

questions.question: This sign indicates that:
questions.answerA: There is a steep hill ahead.
questions.answerB: No trucks are allowed on the upcoming hill.
questions.answerC: A logging road is ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers about an upcoming steep hill. Drivers should slow down and be ready to control their speed and protect their brakes from damage.

questions.question: You come to an intersection that is blocked by other traffic. You should:
questions.answerA: Go slowly until the traffic ahead moves.
questions.answerB: Get as close as possible to the car in front of you.
questions.answerC: Stay out of the intersection until you can pass through.
questions.answerD: Sound your horn to make the cars move up.
questions.explanation: You cannot enter an intersection if traffic is backed up on the other side and you cannot get completely through the intersection. Wait until traffic ahead clears so you do not block the intersection.

questions.question: This sign is a warning that you are approaching:
questions.answerB: A crosswalk.
questions.answerC: A railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that you are approaching a railroad crossing.

questions.question: When a pedestrian guided by a dog or carrying a white cane is crossing the street:
questions.answerA: You must always yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: You must tell them where to cross the street.
questions.answerC: You only have to yield the right-of-way if you are at a corner.
questions.explanation: Blind or partially blind pedestrians may carry a white cane or use the assistance of a guide dog. You must always yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian who is using a guide dog or carrying a white cane.

questions.question: An approaching driver fails to dim their high beam headlights. Where should you look?
questions.answerA: At the wheels of the approaching vehicle.
questions.answerB: Toward the right side of the road.
questions.answerC: Toward the left side of the road.
questions.answerD: Straight down the middle of the road.
questions.explanation: If an approaching driver fails to dim their high beams, glance toward the right side of the road. This will keep you from being blinded by the other vehicle’s headlights and will allow you to see enough of the road to stay on course until the other vehicle has passed.

questions.question: The driver's left arm and hand are extended upward. This hand signal means that the driver plans to:
questions.answerB: Turn right.
questions.answerC: Come to a stop.
questions.explanation: If a driver's left arm and hand are extended upward, they are indicating that they intend to turn right. Adjust your driving accordingly if following a driver who is using this hand signal.

questions.question: What are the consequences of driving under the influence of alcohol or other drugs?
questions.answerB: A mandatory fine
questions.answerC: Driver license revocation
questions.explanation: Driving under the influence can be punished by a fine, jail sentence, and/or suspension or revocation of your license.

questions.question: Fines in a construction zone are:
questions.answerB: Tripled.
questions.answerC: Cut in half.
questions.explanation: Fines for moving traffic violations are doubled in highway construction or maintenance zones where workers are present. When operating in a construction zone, you must drive carefully and follow all directions provided by signs, signals, officers, and flaggers.

questions.question: A steady green traffic light at an intersection means:
questions.answerB: Adjust your mirrors.
questions.answerC: You may continue through the intersection at a safe and reasonable speed, if it is clear to do so.
questions.explanation: A steady green traffic light indicates that the driver may continue through the intersection. The driver should yield to traffic or pedestrians already in the intersection and proceed when the intersection is clear.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and use your low beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Slow down and use your high beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Turn your lights on and off to warn other drivers.
questions.explanation: When driving in fog, you should slow down and use your low beam headlights. If the fog is so bad that you cannot see, pull off the road and wait for the fog to clear.

questions.question: A slow-moving vehicle emblem is:
questions.answerB: A circular green sign.
questions.answerC: A diamond-shaped yellow sign.
questions.explanation: The slow-moving vehicle symbol is a reflective orange triangle. Expect vehicles using this emblem to be driving at speeds of 25 mph or slower.

questions.question: You want to turn right at the next intersection. You should begin to use your turn signal:
questions.answerA: At least 50 feet before the turn.
questions.answerB: When you reach the intersection.
questions.answerC: At least 100 feet before the turn.
questions.answerD: As soon as you see cars behind you.
questions.explanation: The law requires you to signal a turn or lane change with your mechanical turn signals or hand signals at least 100 feet in advance.

questions.question: The safest speed to drive your car:
questions.answerB: Is lower than the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Depends on the weather and road conditions.
questions.answerD: Depends on the mechanical skill of the driver.
questions.explanation: In hazardous conditions, such as when roads are slippery or when weather is foggy, it may be necessary to drive below the posted speed limit. You can be ticketed for driving at a speed that is not reasonable for conditions, even if it's below the legal limit.

questions.question: What might happen when alcohol is combined with another drug?
questions.answerA: The effects of the alcohol and the drug may both be increased.
questions.answerB: Nothing will happen.
questions.answerC: The effects of the alcohol and the drug may both be reduced.
questions.answerD: The effects of only the alcohol may be reduced.
questions.explanation: Consuming both alcohol and another drug may enhance the effects of both. For example, taking one drink when you are also using a cold remedy could affect you as if you have had several drinks.

questions.question: When exiting an expressway, you should:
questions.answerB: Look at the posted speed limit for the road you are entering.
questions.answerC: Cut off other traffic.
questions.explanation: When exiting an expressway, it is important to be alert to other traffic moving nearby. Be sure to look at the new posted speed limit and check your speedometer. It is unlikely that you will be exiting onto a road with a speed limit as high as the one found on the expressway.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: There is a 35 mph speed zone after the curve ahead.
questions.answerB: Drive no slower than 35 mph around the upcoming curve.
questions.answerC: Approach the upcoming curve at a speed of 35 mph or slower.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. These signs may be accompanied by speed advisory plaques that indicate the speed with which you should proceed.

questions.question: You want to turn left at an intersection. The light is green but oncoming traffic is heavy. You should:
questions.answerB: Wait at the crosswalk for traffic to clear.
questions.answerC: Wait in the center of the intersection for traffic to clear.
questions.answerD: Take the right-of-way since you have a green light.
questions.explanation: When making a left turn where there is approaching traffic, you must wait for the approaching traffic to go through before you turn. You may enter the intersection to prepare for your left turn if the light is green and no other vehicle ahead of you plans to make a left turn.

questions.question: You have the right-of-way when you are:
questions.answerB: Backing out of a driveway.
questions.answerC: Leaving a parking space.
questions.explanation: A driver who enters a traffic circle or rotary must yield the right-of-way to drivers already in the circle. Vehicles entering a roadway from a driveway must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and to vehicles already in the road. When leaving a parking space, you must yield to oncoming traffic.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Curves ahead.
questions.answerC: Slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that the road is slippery when wet.

questions.question: Which of the following are factors commonly contributing to traffic crashes?
questions.answerA: Exceeding the posted speed limit and driving too fast for conditions or circumstances.
questions.answerB: Getting adequate rest and staying alert.
questions.answerC: Scanning the environment and staying focused on the driving task.
questions.explanation: Driving above the speed limit, driving too far below the speed limit, and driving too fast for conditions are all actions that commonly contribute to traffic accidents. Always drive with the general flow of traffic, within legal speed limits.

questions.question: When driving past a vehicle that has just stopped in a parked position on the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume that the driver will open the car door as you approach.
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Slam on your brakes.
questions.answerD: Assume that the driver will wait for you to pass before opening the door.
questions.explanation: When passing a vehicle that has just parked parallel to the road, you should assume the driver will open the door as you approach. Use extra caution when driving near parked vehicles.

questions.question: Just like alcohol and other drugs, drowsiness can:
questions.answerA: Help you to be a better driver.
questions.answerB: Make you feel better.
questions.answerC: Impair your judgment.
questions.explanation: Not getting enough sleep is a cause of poor driving behavior. Just like drugs and alcohol, sleepiness slows reaction time, decreases awareness, and impairs judgment.

questions.question: You must yield the right-of-way to an approaching vehicle when you are:
questions.answerB: Already in an intersection.
questions.answerC: Going straight ahead.
questions.explanation: When drivers approach the same intersection from opposite directions at about the same time, drivers turning left must yield to traffic that is going straight or turning right. If a driver traveling straight approaches an intersection where another driver is already making a left turn, they must let that vehicle complete its turn before entering the intersection. Drivers entering a traffic circle or rotary must yield to drivers already in the circle.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Stop sign ahead.
questions.answerC: Divided highway.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that turns in the direction of the arrow (in this case, to the right) are prohibited.

questions.question: You are driving in the right lane of a multilane highway and want to move into the left lane. You should:
questions.answerA: Look in your rearview mirror for traffic behind you before changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Look over your left shoulder for traffic in your blind spot before changing lanes.
questions.answerC: Look in your side mirror for traffic and turn on your directional signal.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, you should always verify that there are no other vehicles in the lane you want to enter by checking your mirrors and looking over your shoulder in the direction you plan to move. You should signal every time you change lanes.

questions.question: As you near an intersection, the traffic light changes from green to yellow. Your best action is to:
questions.answerA: Speed up to beat the red light.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes sharply to stop.
questions.answerC: Be prepared to stop in the center of the intersection.
questions.answerD: Be prepared to stop before the intersection.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow traffic light indicates that the light will soon change to red. You should be prepared to stop for the red light, if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Fire station.
questions.answerC: T intersection.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to an upcoming traffic signal. They should be prepared to respond to a yellow light, red light, and/or cross traffic.

questions.question: A double solid yellow line down the center of a two-lane road indicates:
questions.answerA: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerB: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerD: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines are used to separate traffic moving in opposite directions. Solid lines indicate that drivers are not permitted to pass.

questions.question: If oncoming headlights are blinding you while you are driving at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Look toward the right edge of the road.
questions.answerB: Switch your lights to high beams.
questions.answerC: Turn your lights on and off.
questions.explanation: If the headlights of an oncoming vehicle are blinding, glance toward the right edge of the road instead of looking directly ahead. This should keep your vehicle safely on the road until you pass the oncoming vehicle.

questions.question: Coming to a complete stop at an intersection, yielding to cross traffic/pedestrians, and then proceeding through the intersection when the way is clear corresponds with:
questions.answerB: A flashing yellow light.
questions.answerC: A solid green light.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic light means the same thing as a stop sign. You must come to a complete stop, yield to cross traffic and pedestrians, and then proceed when the way is clear.

questions.question: What does a flashing yellow traffic light mean?
questions.answerB: Proceed with caution.
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow traffic light indicates that you should drive with caution.

questions.question: On long trips, you can prevent drowsiness by:
questions.answerB: Slowing down.
questions.answerC: Stopping at regular intervals for a rest.
questions.answerD: Moving your eyes from side to side as you drive.
questions.explanation: To prevent drowsiness on long trips, you should schedule regular stops. Give yourself time to rest and stretch, even if you are not feeling tired.

questions.question: A diamond-shaped sign is a:
questions.answerB: Interstate route sign.
questions.answerC: School crossing sign.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are normally diamond-shaped and yellow, although orange warning signs are used in work areas. Such signs warn that you are approaching a hazardous location or an area where special rules apply.

questions.question: Motorists should be aware that all bicycles used after dark must have:
questions.answerB: A front headlight and a red taillight.
questions.answerC: White reflectors on the front and rear fenders.
questions.explanation: A bicycle used at night must have a headlight visible from at least 500 feet ahead and a red taillight visible from at least 300 feet behind.

questions.question: You may never park:
questions.answerB: At the entrance of a building.
questions.answerC: In a crosswalk.
questions.answerD: Within 50 feet of a fire hydrant.
questions.explanation: It is illegal to park, stop, or stand within a crosswalk. Parking is prohibited within 15 feet of a fire hydrant.

questions.question: You must stop for a school bus:
questions.answerA: That is parked on the shoulder of the road with no one in it.
questions.answerB: When it approaches you, even if its lights are not flashing.
questions.answerC: If you are both driving on a two-lane highway and its red lights are flashing.
questions.answerD: Whenever the driver waves at you.
questions.explanation: You must stop when approaching a school bus that is displaying flashing red lights while stopped to pick up or drop off children. On a two-lane road, traffic moving in both directions must stop and remain stopped as long as the red lights near the top of the bus are flashing and/or the stop arm on the left side of the bus is extended.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Highway changes ahead and to the right.
questions.answerB: Hiking trails ahead and to the right.
questions.answerC: Hotel ahead and to the right.
questions.answerD: Hospital ahead and to the right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that hospital emergency services are located to the right.

questions.question: You cannot pass safely on a two-way, two-lane street unless:
questions.answerA: You are able to clearly see the road ahead.
questions.answerB: You can return to your lane before meeting oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Your vehicle is capable of the speed necessary to pass.
questions.explanation: You cannot pass safely when driving on a two-way, two-lane street unless you can clearly see the road ahead, you can return to your lane before meeting oncoming traffic, and your vehicle is capable of the speed necessary to pass. Do not pass where it is illegal and unsafe to do so.

questions.question: Your vehicle's stopping distance increases when stopping:
questions.answerA: On a wet or icy road.
questions.answerB: On paved highways.
questions.answerC: When driving at night.
questions.explanation: Stopping distances increase on wet or icy roads. Stopping distances also increase on road surfaces covered in loose gravel or stones.

questions.question: Which of the following commonly causes traffic accidents?
questions.answerB: Excessive speed under the driving conditions
questions.answerC: Following other vehicles too closely
questions.explanation: Driving too fast for conditions is a major cause of motor vehicle crashes. Being inattentive to surroundings can cause a driver to collide with other vehicles. Most rear-end collisions are caused by drivers following other vehicles too closely.

questions.question: When the road is marked with a solid yellow line and a broken yellow line, with the broken line next to your lane, you may pass:
questions.answerB: If you are on an expressway.
questions.answerC: If traffic is clear.
questions.explanation: When there is a solid yellow line and a broken yellow line in the center of the road and the broken line is next to your lane, you may cross the lines to pass if there is no oncoming traffic.

questions.question: Texting while driving is:
questions.answerB: Illegal.
questions.answerC: A safe activity.
questions.answerD: Legal, but only for non-probationary license holders.
questions.explanation: In the state of New York, drivers are not permitted to use a cell phone to type or read a text or email while operating a vehicle. Texting while driving can result in a fine of up to $450.

questions.question: What should you do when you are going to enter a roadway from a private road?
questions.answerA: Blow your horn to warn cars you are entering the roadway.
questions.answerB: Stop with part of your car on the roadway to alert other drivers.
questions.answerC: Drive out fast to merge smoothly with the traffic.
questions.answerD: Yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and roadway traffic.
questions.explanation: When entering a roadway from a driveway or private road, you must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and traffic on the roadway.

questions.question: After you have passed a car, you may return to the right lane when you:
questions.answerA: See the front bumper of the other car in your rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Have put your turn signal on.
questions.answerC: Have turned your headlights on.
questions.answerD: See the other car's headlights turn on.
questions.explanation: After passing on the left, before you return to the right lane, look at your interior rearview mirror and make sure you can see the front bumper of the passed vehicle. Look over your right shoulder to make sure you can see several feet of pavement between your vehicle and the one you passed. You may then return to the right lane.

questions.question: If there is a deep puddle on the road ahead, you should:
questions.answerA: Maintain the posted speed to make it through the water.
questions.answerB: Avoid the puddle if possible.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral as you drive through the water.
questions.explanation: To prevent skidding on slippery surfaces, avoid especially slippery areas, such as ice patches, wet leaves, oil, or deep puddles. The safest surface for driving is a dry, solid surface.

questions.question: When may you legally drive around or under a railroad crossing gate?
questions.answerB: When you can see clearly in both directions.
questions.answerC: When the warning lights are not flashing.
questions.explanation: Do not go around or under any lowered gate at a railroad crossing. Once the gate is raised, do not proceed across the tracks until you can see clearly in both directions and are sure there are no trains coming.

questions.question: You may not park:
questions.answerB: In a parking lot.
questions.answerC: On a crosswalk or in a marked bicycle lane.
questions.answerD: Within 12 inches of the right side of the road.
questions.explanation: There are a number of locations where it is unlawful to park, including on a crosswalk or in a marked bicycle lane. When parking on the street, you must be within 12 inches of the side of the road.

questions.question: At a crosswalk:
questions.answerB: Pedestrians must yield to you.
questions.answerC: Construction workers must yield to you.
questions.explanation: Pedestrians have the right-of-way at street crossings but must obey traffic control signals. Where a traffic signal is not present, vehicles must stop for pedestrians in a crosswalk, whether it is marked or unmarked.

questions.question: What is the appropriate action to take when approaching a railroad crossing that does not have signals to direct traffic?
questions.answerA: Always bring the car to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: Slow down and be prepared to stop.
questions.answerC: All railroad crossings have signals so you will never encounter this situation.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed to get across the tracks quickly.
questions.explanation: When approaching an unmarked railroad crossing, slow down and be prepared to stop. Before you cross, be sure that no trains are approaching from either direction on any track. If you see or hear a train coming, stop at a safe distance from the nearest track and wait to proceed until after the train passes.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Intersection ahead.
questions.answerC: Merging traffic from the right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is merging traffic entering from the right.

questions.question: You may pass another vehicle on the right if it is waiting to:
questions.answerB: Turn left.
questions.answerC: Park at the curb.
questions.answerD: Turn into a driveway on the right.
questions.explanation: While you generally may pass only on the left, there are certain conditions under which passing on the right is permitted. You should only pass on the right if you can do so safely and you do not need to drive on or across the shoulder or edge line of the road. One situation where passing on the right is allowed is when the vehicle in front of you is making a left turn.

questions.question: To avoid collisions with vehicles in your blind spots, you should:
questions.answerA: Quickly turn your head to see if your blind spot is clear before changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Adjust your rearview mirrors every few minutes.
questions.answerC: Honk your horn right before turning or changing lanes.
questions.explanation: Before turning or changing lanes, turn your head and glance over your shoulder in the direction of your move to see if your blind spot is clear. Never rely on your mirrors alone.

questions.question: When driving at night on a dimly lit street, you should:
questions.answerA: Drive slowly enough that you can stop within the area illuminated by your headlights.
questions.answerB: Turn on your high beam headlights to better see the vehicles ahead of you.
questions.answerC: Keep the instrument panel lights bright to be more visible to other drivers.
questions.explanation: You should drive more slowly at night than during the day because it is not possible to see as far ahead at night. You should make sure that you can stop within the area illuminated by your headlights.

questions.question: What does this road sign mean?
questions.answerA: Slow down and prepare to stop if cars are approaching you.
questions.answerB: Come to a full stop and go when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Proceed carefully through the intersection, not always stopping.
questions.answerD: Stop only for traffic on an intersecting road.
questions.explanation: A stop sign means that you must come to a full stop and yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians in or heading toward the intersection. Go again when it is safe.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: The road ahead curves left, then right.
questions.answerC: The road ahead curves right, then left.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead curves to the right and then to the left. You should slow down to be able to negotiate these curves safely.

questions.question: You may drive around or under a gate that is being lowered or raised at a railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: As long as an approaching train is not too close.
questions.answerB: If your vehicle can do so without damaging the gate.
questions.answerC: If you first look carefully in both directions.
questions.explanation: Flashing red lights, lowered crossing gates, and/or bells at a railroad crossing mean that you must come to a complete stop. You must not go across the tracks until the lights and bells have stopped and the crossing gates are completely up. Do not drive around or under a gate that is moving up or down.

questions.question: What happens if you refuse to take a chemical test?
questions.answerA: There is no evidence to find you guilty of drunk driving.
questions.answerB: You cannot be arrested for drunk driving.
questions.answerC: Your license will be taken away.
questions.explanation: New York has an Implied Consent Law, which means that by driving in the state, you have given your consent to a chemical test if you are arrested for an alcohol- or drug-related violation. If you refuse to take the test, your license will be suspended. If a DMV hearing later confirms that you refused the test, your driver license will be revoked, even if you are found not guilty of the original charge.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: You must stop ahead.
questions.answerC: Speeding is not allowed.
questions.answerD: There is a traffic signal ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a traffic signal ahead.

questions.question: When braking on slippery surfaces, you should apply the brakes:
questions.answerB: Later than usual.
questions.answerC: More abruptly than usual.
questions.explanation: When braking on slippery surfaces, such as roads covered in snow or ice, you should apply your brakes steadily and slowly to avoid locking your brakes. Apply the brakes earlier than you would on a different surface to allow your vehicle extra time to safely slow down.

questions.question: When driving in traffic, it is safest to:
questions.answerA: Fluctuate your speed to keep alert.
questions.answerB: Drive faster than the flow of traffic.
questions.answerC: Drive slower than the flow of traffic.
questions.answerD: Drive with the flow of traffic.
questions.explanation: Crashes often happen when some drivers go faster or slower than other vehicles on the road. Always try to drive with the flow of traffic, within the posted speed limit.

questions.question: Highway pavement will be particularly treacherous and most slippery:
questions.answerA: If it has been raining several hours.
questions.answerB: If it has just begun to rain.
questions.answerC: If it has been raining for one to two hours.
questions.explanation: Pavement is particularly treacherous when it first begins to rain. Accumulations of dirt and oil mix with the rainwater, creating a greasy film on the roadway.

questions.question: You come to an intersection displaying a flashing red light. You should:
questions.answerA: Come to a full stop and go when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerB: Stop only if other cars are also approaching the intersection.
questions.answerC: Stop only if other cars are already within the intersection.
questions.answerD: Slow down and be prepared to stop, if necessary.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic light has the same meaning as a stop sign. You must stop, yield the right-of-way, and go once it is safe.

questions.question: Many crashes are caused by:
questions.answerA: Drivers traveling too fast for conditions.
questions.answerB: Drivers consistently checking their mirrors and blind spots.
questions.answerC: Drivers yielding the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: Drivers maintaining a four-second following distance.
questions.explanation: Many crashes are caused by drivers who are driving too fast for conditions. Always drive within the legal speed limits and decrease your speed any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: If your car's suspension is bad, it can cause:
questions.answerB: Squealing brakes.
questions.answerC: Slack in the steering.
questions.explanation: Your suspension helps you control your vehicle and provides a comfortable ride over varying road surfaces. If your vehicle bounces a lot after driving over a bump, or is generally hard to control, you may need new suspension parts.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Lane reduction; the right lane ends soon.
questions.answerC: Highway entrance ramp ahead.
questions.answerD: Lane reduction; the left lane ends soon.
questions.explanation: This sign indicate that the right lane ends ahead.

questions.question: If you drink alcohol socially, what helps ensure safe driving?
questions.answerB: Ride home with a friend who has not been drinking.
questions.answerC: Take a cold shower before driving.
questions.answerD: Stop drinking one half hour before driving.
questions.explanation: One strategy to avoid driving while impaired or intoxicated is to arrange for a ride home with a friend who does not drink. Drinking coffee or taking a cold shower cannot reduce your blood alcohol content or reduce the effects of alcohol. On average, it takes about an hour for the body to eliminate the alcohol from a single drink.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Divided highway ahead.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of two-way traffic ahead.

questions.question: When you see other drivers around you acting or reacting in anger:
questions.answerB: Don't react with hand gestures.
questions.answerC: Distance yourself from the situation.
questions.explanation: When other drivers are behaving angrily, you should take action to physically and mentally distance yourself from the situation. Avoid making eye contact with them, or making body movements or gestures that could provoke them. Slow down, move over, or do whatever you safely can to put yourself out of danger.

questions.question: A person who drives much slower than the speed limit:
questions.answerB: Always has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Should not let following cars pass.
questions.answerD: May create a dangerous driving environment.
questions.explanation: Driving more slowly than the flow of traffic can be hazardous. If you are on a two-lane, two-way road and driving so slowly that traffic is backing up behind you, you are required to pull off the road and let the other vehicles pass. Only drive significantly under the speed limit when conditions require it.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Hill ahead.
questions.answerC: Truck stop ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that there is a steep hill ahead.

questions.question: What are the colors of signs that tell you the distance to the next exit on a highway?
questions.answerB: Black with white letters
questions.answerC: Red with white letters
questions.explanation: Signs providing information about destinations are green with white letters or symbols.

questions.question: You are driving in the middle lane on a three-lane expressway. A car begins to pass you on the right. The actions of that driver are:
questions.answerA: Wrong because “pass to the left” is a firm rule.
questions.answerB: Wrong because they are passing you in your blind spot.
questions.answerC: Fine, as long as it is done on a limited-access highway.
questions.answerD: Fine, as long as no signs forbid passing on the right.
questions.explanation: On a two-way road with two or more lanes traveling in the same direction, it is permitted to pass on the right as long as doing so is not prohibited by signs or restricted by parked cars or other obstructions.

questions.question: How many alcoholic drinks does it take to affect your driving ability?
questions.answerB: Two
questions.answerC: One
questions.explanation: It is not advisable to drive after drinking any amount of alcohol. Even a single drink will affect your ability to drive safely.

questions.question: You are driving along a street and hear a siren. You cannot immediately see the emergency vehicle. You should:
questions.answerA: Keep driving until you see the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Pull to the curb and look to see if it is on your street.
questions.answerC: Slow down. Don't stop until you see it.
questions.answerD: Speed up and turn at the next intersection.
questions.explanation: If you hear a siren or an air horn close by but do not know exactly where the emergency vehicle is, safely pull over to the right side of the road and stop until you are sure it is not headed toward you.

questions.question: To avoid glare from the headlights of an approaching car:
questions.answerA: Look briefly toward the right side of the road.
questions.answerB: Stay focused on the centerline on the road.
questions.answerC: Flash your high beams.
questions.explanation: You should avoid looking toward the bright lights of an oncoming vehicle by glancing toward the right side of the road. After looking briefly toward the side of the road, continue looking ahead to check on the position of the other vehicle.

questions.question: At a red traffic light with a green arrow, you may proceed in the direction of the arrow if:
questions.answerA: You first come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: You wait until the light changes.
questions.answerC: You are in the proper lane and the roadway is clear.
questions.explanation: If you are in a lane corresponding to a signal displaying a green arrow, you may proceed in the direction of the arrow when the way is clear. This is true whether the arrow is displayed alone or together with another signal.

questions.question: If you are parked parallel to the curb, you may get out of the car on the traffic side only:
questions.answerA: During the daytime when other drivers can see you.
questions.answerB: When the traffic light at the closest intersection turns red.
questions.answerC: When you won't interfere with oncoming vehicles.
questions.answerD: If you use your four-way flashers first.
questions.explanation: After parallel parking, you must not open your door if it will interfere with bicyclists or other traffic. Check for traffic before exiting your vehicle.

questions.question: Roads with double solid yellow line markings down the center indicate that passing is:
questions.answerB: Allowed only from your direction of travel.
questions.answerC: Not allowed from either direction.
questions.explanation: A double solid yellow line down the center of a road indicates that traffic is moving in opposite directions and that passing is not allowed from either direction.

questions.question: On a road which has no sidewalks, a pedestrian should walk on the:
questions.answerA: Side of the road which has the lightest traffic.
questions.answerB: Same side of the road on which traffic is moving.
questions.answerC: Side of the road facing oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: Side of the road which has the heaviest traffic.
questions.explanation: Pedestrians should walk on the side of the road facing the traffic in the lane nearest them.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about BAC (blood alcohol content)?
questions.answerA: The breathalyzer is a test to determine a person's BAC.
questions.answerB: A chemical test for BAC is needed for an alcohol conviction.
questions.answerC: BAC levels are reduced by a person's physical fitness.
questions.answerD: After drinking, coffee or a cold shower will lower your BAC.
questions.explanation: A breathalyzer is a chemical test to determine a person's BAC. A chemical test is not required for the conviction of an alcohol-related offense. A police officer's testimony about how a person was driving, or their appearance and behavior when arrested, is enough.

questions.question: If you have trouble seeing other vehicles because of dust or smoke blowing across the roadway, you should drive more slowly and turn on your:
questions.answerB: Parking lights.
questions.answerC: Headlights.
questions.explanation: You must turn on your headlights any time conditions prevent you from seeing other vehicles. Other drivers may have trouble seeing you, too.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Stop ahead.
questions.answerC: Roadwork or maintenance is present.
questions.explanation: Orange, diamond-shaped signs are used to mark construction, maintenance, survey, and utility work areas. These signs help direct drivers and pedestrians safely through dangerous zones. Fines for traffic convictions may double in areas marked by these signs.

questions.question: A “No standing” sign at a certain location means:
questions.answerA: You may never stop your vehicle there.
questions.answerB: You may park there if the driver remains in the vehicle.
questions.answerC: You may stop temporarily only to pickup or discharge passengers.
questions.answerD: You may stop to load or unload merchandise.
questions.explanation: A "No standing" sign means that you may only make a temporary stop to load or discharge passengers.

questions.question: Distracted driving is:
questions.answerB: Extremely risky behavior.
questions.answerC: Nothing to be concerned about.
questions.answerD: No less safe than driving under any other conditions.
questions.explanation: Distracted driving is extremely risky behavior that puts not only you and your passengers in danger, but also endangers pedestrians, bicyclists, and other motorists sharing the road. Focused attention on driving helps to prevent crashes.

questions.question: When you approach a railroad crossing without flashing warning signals or crossing gates, you should:
questions.answerA: Cross the tracks immediately and as quickly as possible.
questions.answerB: Always stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: Prepare to yield to any train at the crossing.
questions.answerD: Speed up to beat any oncoming train.
questions.explanation: Always be prepared to yield to any oncoming trains before crossing railroad tracks, particularly if there are no lights or gates controlling the crossing. Never start to cross the tracks until there is room for your entire vehicle on the other side of the tracks. Due to the risk of a vehicle stalling, it is not wise to shift gears when crossing railroad tracks.

questions.question: What does alcohol do to your driving skills and judgement?
questions.answerA: It helps driving skills but harms your judgement.
questions.answerB: It harms both driving skills and judgement.
questions.answerC: It has no effect on either driving skills or judgement.
questions.answerD: It has no effect on judgement but it harms driving skills.
questions.explanation: Alcohol negatively affects many skills needed for safe driving, including your reaction time and ability to see clearly. It can also harm your judgment of speed and distance, lower your inhibitions, and make you more prone to taking chances.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Merging traffic is approaching from the left.
questions.answerB: Winding road ahead.
questions.answerC: Right lane ends ahead, merge left.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the right lane ends ahead and drivers must merge left.

questions.question: How can you lower the risk of hydroplaning?
questions.answerA: Do not speed when the roads are wet.
questions.answerB: Use tires with proper air pressure.
questions.answerC: Replace tires with bad tread.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning happens when a vehicle glides on top of a thin layer of water between its tires and the road. Tires with low air pressure or bad tread can increase the risk of hydroplaning. Speeding also increases the risk.

questions.question: You are driving on a divided multilane highway and see or hear the signal of an approaching emergency vehicle. You should:
questions.answerA: Disregard the signal if there are other lanes available for the emergency vehicle.
questions.answerB: Stop as quickly as you can.
questions.answerC: Slow down, move your vehicle to provide a clear path for the emergency vehicle, and stop.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed to get out of the way of the emergency vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you hear the siren or see the flashing lights of an emergency vehicle, you must slow down, provide a clear path for the vehicle, and stop. Don't try to outdrive the emergency vehicle.

questions.question: A driver may park in a space reserved for people with disabilities if the vehicle displays the proper license plates:
questions.answerA: Regardless of who is in the vehicle.
questions.answerB: And only if the driver is disabled.
questions.answerC: And is carrying the disabled person named on the registration.
questions.answerD: And someone in the driver's immediate family is disabled.
questions.explanation: To park in a space reserved for people with disabilities, the vehicle must be in operation to transport the disabled person named on the registration or permit.

questions.question: If you are driving and you see animals standing near the roadway:
questions.answerA: Speed up to scare them away.
questions.answerB: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.answerC: Quickly swerve into the next lane.
questions.explanation: Slow down and proceed with caution if you see animals that are standing near the roadway. They may unexpectedly bolt or change direction at the last moment. Some animals travel in packs, so there may be more animals just out of sight that are also near the road.

questions.question: A flashing red light on a traffic signal means:
questions.answerA: The same thing as a stop sign.
questions.answerB: The traffic signal is broken.
questions.answerC: You do not have to come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: A flashing red light means the same thing as a stop sign. If you encounter a flashing red light, you should come to a complete stop, yield to appropriate traffic and pedestrians, and only proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: When you park uphill on a street with a curb:
questions.answerA: Keep the front wheel straight and set the parking brake.
questions.answerB: Turn the front wheels away from the curb.
questions.answerC: Turn the front wheels toward the curb.
questions.answerD: Turn the back wheels into the curb.
questions.explanation: When parking on an incline where there is a curb, you should turn your wheels sharply to the left, away from the curb. This way, if your brakes fail, your vehicle will not roll into traffic.

questions.question: If you are being followed too closely on a two-lane road:
questions.answerA: Reduce your speed slowly to encourage the tailgater to drive around you.
questions.answerB: Speed up to increase the distance between you and the other car.
questions.answerC: Apply your brakes to slow down, then resume your original speed.
questions.explanation: If you are being followed too closely by another driver, merge into a different lane. If there is no lane available for merging, wait until the road ahead is clear and slowly reduce your speed. This will encourage the tailgater to drive around you.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Winding road.
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates a low ground railroad crossing. Where this sign is present, railroad tracks cross the road at a steep slope and the bottom of low vehicles may drag or get caught on the tracks.

questions.question: When parallel parked, your vehicle may be no more than ____ from the curb.
questions.answerB: Six inches
questions.answerC: Three inches
questions.explanation: When parallel parked, your vehicle should be no more than one foot from the curb. Be sure surrounding vehicles have room to leave their parking spaces.

questions.question: Which of these is a safe driving technique?
questions.answerA: Using your high beam lights in the fog.
questions.answerB: Staring at the road ahead of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Checking your rearview mirrors frequently.
questions.explanation: To stay aware of hazards, you should scan the road and check your rearview mirrors every two to five seconds. Constantly staring at just the road ahead of you is dangerous. If you must drive in foggy conditions, you should use your low beam headlights, not your high beam headlights.

questions.question: In a parking space reserved for people with disabilities, a driver with no disabled person on board:
questions.answerB: May not park, but may stop in an emergency.
questions.answerC: May not park or stop, but may stand in an emergency.
questions.answerD: May not park, stop, or stand.
questions.explanation: It is illegal to stop, stand, or park in a space reserved for disabled persons unless the vehicle has plates or a permit for such spaces and the person who is named on the plates or permit is in the vehicle.

questions.question: Which vehicles must stop at all railroad crossings?
questions.answerB: School buses and occupied passenger buses
questions.answerC: Motorcycles
questions.explanation: School buses (with or without passengers), transit buses with passengers onboard, and vehicles carrying explosives or flammable cargo must stop at all railroad crossings.

questions.question: What are the colors of warning signs indicating upcoming hazards?
questions.answerA: Black letters or symbols on a white background
questions.answerB: Black letters or symbols on a yellow background
questions.answerC: White letters or symbols on a blue background
questions.answerD: White letters or symbols on a green background
questions.explanation: Warning signs that indicate approaching hazards are usually yellow with black lettering or symbols. Warning signs in work zones are orange with black lettering or symbols.

questions.question: When you want to make a right turn, your car must be:
questions.answerA: Near the center of the street.
questions.answerB: Close to the left side of the street.
questions.answerC: Close to the right side of the street.
questions.answerD: Past the center of the intersection when you begin to turn.
questions.explanation: As you prepare to make a right turn, you should get as far to the right side of the road as possible. Do not cut across lanes of traffic to perform any turn.

questions.question: When approaching a flashing red traffic light, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Drive through the intersection if there is no crossing traffic.
questions.answerB: Continue driving, as they have the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Stop if a police officer is nearby.
questions.answerD: Treat the light like a stop sign.
questions.explanation: Flashing red lights are used at dangerous intersections. Treat them like stop signs.

questions.question: If you need to pass behind a tractor-trailer that is backing up, you should:
questions.answerB: Wait for the truck to stop backing up before you begin passing.
questions.answerC: Honk to let the driver know you are passing.
questions.answerD: Assume that the driver can see you.
questions.explanation: Large vehicles have large blind spots to the rear. If you are behind a large vehicle, it is very likely that the driver does not know you are there. Because of this, if you need to pass behind a large vehicle that is backing up, it is always the safest option to wait for the truck's backup maneuver to finish before you pass.

questions.question: Drinking alcohol and driving is:
questions.answerB: A serious traffic safety problem.
questions.answerC: Safe if you have only had a few drinks.
questions.answerD: Only dangerous to the driver who drinks.
questions.explanation: Driving while impaired or intoxicated is a serious traffic safety problem. Safe driving is not possible when you drink alcohol or take other drugs. Driving under the influence is dangerous both to you and to others on the road.

questions.question: You may pass a vehicle when:
questions.answerA: You are on a hill or curve.
questions.answerB: You are on a road with a solid line next to your lane.
questions.answerC: You are on a road with a broken line next to your lane.
questions.explanation: A single broken line indicates that drivers may cross from either lane to change lanes. Dashed yellow lines alongside solid yellow lines indicate that passing is permitted from the lane next to the broken line, but not from the lane next to the solid line. Only change lanes when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Which statement about speed is true?
questions.answerA: Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous.
questions.answerB: Speeding can kill.
questions.answerC: Speeding is not dangerous if you are a skilled driver.
questions.answerD: Both "Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous" and "Speeding can kill."
questions.explanation: As speed increases, the chance of a fatality increases. If you are moving faster than 80 miles per hour, you have almost no chance of living through a crash. Driving more slowly than other traffic can also be dangerous because other motorists may become impatient and make dangerous moves to pass you.

questions.question: Blood alcohol content (BAC) depends on each of the following, except:
questions.answerB: How much you drink.
questions.answerC: How much time passes between drinks.
questions.explanation: Your blood alcohol content (BAC) depends on how much alcohol you drink, how much time passes between drinks, and your weight. It is not affected by the type of alcoholic beverages you drink, your level of physical fitness, or how well you can "hold your liquor."

questions.question: When a bicyclist is making a left turn:
questions.answerA: They may use the left lane.
questions.answerB: They may cut through all lanes.
questions.answerC: They may wait on the side of the road.
questions.explanation: You should expect to see bicyclists driving with traffic on the road. You should not be surprised to see a bicyclist using the left lane when turning.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: You are approaching the end of a divided highway.
questions.answerB: You are approaching the beginning of a divided highway.
questions.answerC: The road will be slippery ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a divided highway begins ahead. Keep to the right of the median divider.

questions.question: Having a driver license is a:
questions.answerB: Privilege, not a right.
questions.answerC: Requirement.
questions.explanation: Holding a driver license is not a right. It is a privilege that must be earned and maintained.

questions.question: When entering an interstate highway, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop, check for cars, and enter when safe.
questions.answerB: Check for cars and reduce your speed to 25 mph before entering the traffic lane.
questions.answerC: Check for cars, increase your speed to match the flow of traffic, and merge when the way is clear.
questions.explanation: Rather than stopping (as you would when entering other roads), you must use the merging or acceleration lane to speed up and smoothly merge with fast-moving traffic already on the interstate.

questions.question: You are waiting in the intersection to complete a left turn. You should:
questions.answerA: Signal and keep your wheels turned to the left.
questions.answerB: Signal and keep your wheels straight.
questions.answerC: Flash your headlights so drivers will let you through.
questions.answerD: Drive around the rear of a car if it blocks you.
questions.explanation: You must always signal before turning or changing lanes. You should keep your wheels straight while waiting to make a left turn. If another vehicle hits you from behind, this ensures that you will not be pushed into oncoming traffic.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Intersection ahead.
questions.answerC: Hiking trails ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a school crossing is ahead.

questions.question: When driving at night, you should:
questions.answerB: Look directly at the headlights of an oncoming vehicle.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: Increase your following distance when it is difficult to see due to darkness. Use headlights to increase visibility, following the rules for proper use of high beams and low beams. Avoid looking directly at the headlights of an oncoming vehicle to avoid being blinded by the glare.

questions.question: Which of the following does not happen after drinking?
questions.answerA: Your reflexes and reaction time slow down.
questions.answerB: Your judgement of speed and distance is distorted.
questions.answerC: You are less alert.
questions.answerD: You calm down and can concentrate better.
questions.explanation: Alcohol reduces your reaction time, reduces your ability to see clearly, changes your judgment of speed and distances, reduces your ability to recover from the glare of headlights, and often reduces your inhibitions and makes you more likely to take risks.

questions.question: When driving in bad weather, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Increase their speed to reach their final destination more quickly.
questions.answerB: Decrease their following distance.
questions.answerC: Increase their following distance.
questions.explanation: When driving on wet roads, drivers should increase their following distance.

questions.question: When merging onto the freeway, you should be driving:
questions.answerA: At or near the speed of the freeway traffic.
questions.answerB: At the legal speed limit.
questions.answerC: More slowly than the freeway traffic.
questions.explanation: You should enter a freeway at or near the speed of traffic, unless the speed of traffic exceeds the legal speed limit.

questions.question: Which of the following signs is rectangular?
questions.answerB: Railroad crossing sign
questions.answerC: Stop sign
questions.explanation: Regulation signs are normally white rectangles with black lettering or symbols. These signs may give information about various kinds of special rules, including speed limits.

questions.question: You may cross double solid yellow lines:
questions.answerB: To turn into a driveway.
questions.answerC: To pass another car.
questions.explanation: Double solid lines indicate that you may not pass or change lanes. You cannot cross the lines unless it is to turn left to enter or exit a highway, to turn into or from a driveway, or to make a U-turn (where permitted).

questions.question: Double solid yellow line markings down the center of a road indicate that passing is:
questions.answerB: Allowed only from your direction of travel.
questions.answerC: Not allowed from either direction.
questions.explanation: A double yellow centerline means that it is prohibited for traffic from either direction to cross the centerline to pass.

questions.question: You are approaching an intersection when the traffic light changes from green to solid yellow. You should:
questions.answerA: Consider it the same as a caution sign and continue through the intersection.
questions.answerB: Stop immediately.
questions.answerC: Stop before entering the intersection, unless you are too close to stop safely.
questions.answerD: Speed up to get through the intersection before the red light appears.
questions.explanation: When approaching an intersection with a solid yellow traffic light, slow to a stop before entering the intersection, if it is safe to do so. If you can't stop safely, drive carefully through the intersection.

questions.question: You are approaching a railroad crossing that has no visible gates or flashing lights, but has a standard crossbuck. You should:
questions.answerA: Approach all tracks with extreme caution and cross only when you know that there is no train coming.
questions.answerB: Turn your radio down to hear if there may be an approaching train.
questions.answerC: Only continue once cleared to do so by a flagger, if applicable.
questions.explanation: You must approach all railroad crossings with extreme caution and cross only when you know that no train is coming from either direction. If there is a flagger at a crossing, you must obey all of their instructions.

questions.question: If you are about to be hit from the rear, you should consider each of the following, except for:
questions.answerB: Letting go of the steering wheel.
questions.answerC: Pressing your head firmly against the head restraint.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle is hit from the rear while you are in forward motion, your body will be thrown backward. Press yourself against the back of your seat and put your head against the head restraint to prevent whiplash. Maintain a firm grip on the steering wheel and be ready to apply your brakes to avoid being pushed into another vehicle.

questions.question: This is a ____ sign.
questions.answerB: Wrong way
questions.answerC: Yield
questions.explanation: This triangular sign is a "Yield" sign. When you see this sign, you must slow down to check for traffic and yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and approaching cross traffic. Stop only if it is necessary to do so.

questions.question: Traffic signals sometimes display arrows to control turns from specific lanes. A green arrow:
questions.answerA: Is used only on one-way streets.
questions.answerB: Has the same meaning as a circular green traffic light, but traffic must turn in the direction indicated by the arrow.
questions.answerC: Means that you may proceed, but only if the green arrow is accompanied by a circular green light.
questions.answerD: Points the way to an airport.
