questions.explanation: A green arrow has the same meaning as a circular green traffic light, but traffic in the indicated lane must turn in the direction shown by the arrow.

questions.question: If an approaching train is near enough or going fast enough to be a danger, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.answerB: Not cross the tracks until the train has completely passed.
questions.answerC: Cross the tracks at your own risk.
questions.answerD: Find an alternative route across tracks.
questions.explanation: You should look and listen for trains before crossing any railroad tracks. If an approaching train is near enough or going fast enough to be a danger, you cannot go across the tracks. This is true even if they have no signals or the signals are not working.

questions.question: Drinking coffee after drinking alcohol:
questions.answerB: Cancels the effect of the alcohol.
questions.answerC: Has no effect on blood alcohol concentration.
questions.explanation: Drinking coffee will not reduce your blood alcohol concentration (BAC). While it may help you to stay awake, it cannot change your BAC or make you sober.

questions.question: To help prevent crashes, you should:
questions.answerB: Ignore other drivers on the road.
questions.answerC: Drive only on side streets and back roads.
questions.explanation: Crashes often happen because one driver does something that other road users are not expecting. You should communicate with other motorists, bicyclists, and pedestrians by doing things like signaling when slowing down, stopping, or changing direction. Use your emergency signals or horn when appropriate.

questions.question: "No zones" are areas around trucks where cars:
questions.answerA: Disappear into blind spots or are so close that they restrict the truck driver's ability to stop and maneuver safely.
questions.answerB: Have sufficient space to travel behind the truck.
questions.answerC: Have several car lengths between their vehicle and the truck.
questions.explanation: "No zones" are areas around trucks or buses in which cars disappear into the larger vehicle's blind spots. "No zones" can also be defined as areas in which cars are so close to the larger vehicle that they restrict the truck or bus driver’s ability to stop and maneuver safely. A car being in a "No zone" greatly increases the potential for a crash.

questions.question: A red and white triangular sign at an intersection means:
questions.answerA: Slow down if an emergency vehicle is approaching.
questions.answerB: Look both ways as you cross the intersection.
questions.answerC: Always come to a full stop at the intersection.
questions.answerD: Slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.
questions.explanation: A triangular red and white yield sign means that you must decrease speed as you approach an intersection and yield the right-of-way to any vehicles or pedestrians in the intersection. You must be prepared to stop if conditions require it.

questions.question: Defensive driving is:
questions.answerA: Identifying dangerous driving situations and taking action to avoid accidents.
questions.answerB: Defending yourself against poor drivers by getting ahead of them in traffic.
questions.answerC: Following the vehicle ahead of you at a close distance.
questions.answerD: Quickly changing lanes and shifting in and out of traffic congestion.
questions.explanation: You drive defensively when you identify dangerous driving situations and take action before an accident occurs. Defensive driving helps prevent conflicts with aggressive, offensive, discourteous, careless, inattentive, impulsive, ignorant, or intoxicated drivers or pedestrians.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No stopping.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that U-turns are prohibited.

questions.question: Which of the following must you obey over the other three?
questions.answerB: A police officer
questions.answerC: A stop sign
questions.explanation: Directions given by traffic officers take precedence over signs, signals, and pavement markings. People authorized to direct traffic include police officers, fire police, highway work area flag persons, and school crossing persons.

questions.question: To safely pass a bicycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Honk at the bicyclist to let them know you're trying to pass.
questions.answerB: Drive in the bicycle lane until you get a chance to pass.
questions.answerC: Slow down and give them as much space as possible.
questions.answerD: Rush ahead to pull in front of the bicyclist.
questions.explanation: When passing a bicyclist, slow down and give them as much space as you can. Bicyclists have much less protection than drivers of motor vehicles and they should not be crowded. Passing a bicycle too quickly can shift the bicyclist off-course.

questions.question: Crossbuck signs indicate:
questions.answerB: School zones.
questions.answerC: No passing zones.
questions.explanation: Crossbuck signs tell drivers to yield to trains at a railroad crossing. Drivers should not try to outdrive a train.

questions.question: Which of the following blocks the smooth flow of traffic?
questions.answerA: Slowing down to look at collision scene.
questions.answerB: Avoiding unnecessary lane changes.
questions.answerC: Using public transportation instead of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Rubbernecking (the practice of slowing down to look at collisions or other out-of-the-ordinary things) contributes to traffic congestion and should be avoided.

questions.question: What is the only way to reduce your blood alcohol concentration (BAC)?
questions.answerB: Exercise.
questions.answerC: Allow your body time to get rid of the alcohol.
questions.explanation: The only method that effectively reduces your BAC is to not drink alcohol for a period of time. Coffee, exercise, and cold showers cannot reduce your BAC or change the effects of alcohol. They can help you remain awake, but they cannot change your BAC or make you sober.

questions.question: The driver's left arm and hand are extended downward. This hand signal means that the driver plans to:
questions.answerB: Turn right.
questions.answerC: Stop.
questions.explanation: If a driver's left arm and hand are extended downward, they are indicating that they intend to stop. Adjust your driving accordingly if following a driver who is using this hand signal.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Divided highway starts.
questions.answerC: Divided highway ends.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns that the divided highway ends ahead. Prepare to change lanes or shift lane position.

questions.question: One of the strategies of defensive driving is:
questions.answerA: Looking straight ahead as you drive.
questions.answerB: Staying alert and keeping your eyes moving.
questions.answerC: Expecting that other drivers will make up for your errors.
questions.answerD: Being confident that you can avoid danger at the last minute.
questions.explanation: Because traffic conditions are always changing, you should consistently scan the road ahead. Keep your eyes moving, notice what is happening at the sides of the road, and check behind you every few seconds by using your mirrors.

questions.question: You may not cross a single broken white or yellow line:
questions.answerA: When doing so would interfere with traffic.
questions.answerB: When turning left into a driveway.
questions.answerC: When the car in front of you is disabled.
questions.answerD: When passing to the right on a one-way street.
questions.explanation: You may cross a single broken line to pass or change lanes as long as you can do so safely and without interfering with traffic.

questions.question: A regulatory sign containing a red circle with a slash through the middle indicates:
questions.answerA: That drivers should come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: That an action is forbidden.
questions.answerC: That some drivers should yield to other drivers.
questions.answerD: That drivers should drive under the speed limit.
questions.explanation: Some regulatory signs prohibit certain actions. These signs are rectangular and white with red and black markings. A red circle and slash on top of a black symbol indicates that the specified action is forbidden.

questions.question: When you see this sign, it means:
questions.answerA: There is an object on the roadway.
questions.answerB: Traffic is coming from the right.
questions.answerC: The road is curving sharply to the left.
questions.answerD: There is a merge point ahead.
questions.explanation: Chevron signs like this indicate that the road curves sharply in the direction indicated by the chevron (in this case, to the left). There may be several chevron signs placed throughout a curve.

questions.question: What happens if you drink alcohol while taking prescription or over-the-counter medicine?
questions.answerA: The medicine reduces the effect of the alcohol.
questions.answerB: The alcohol will help the medicine cure a cold.
questions.answerC: The combination could multiply the effects of the alcohol or medicine.
questions.answerD: There is no effect because they are different substances.
questions.explanation: Consuming alcohol and other drugs together can increase the impairing effects of both. For example, having one drink while you are also using a cold remedy could affect you as much as several drinks would when being consumed separately from any medications.

questions.question: If you come to an intersection and your view to the side is blocked, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and look both ways.
questions.answerB: Maintain your speed and look both ways.
questions.answerC: Stop, then inch forward until you can see clearly in both directions.
questions.explanation: Drivers must slow down when approaching an intersection. If a clear view of cross traffic is obscured, a driver should come to a stop and inch forward until they can see clearly in both directions.

questions.question: An intersection has a stop sign and crosswalk, but no stop line. You must stop:
questions.answerB: 50 feet before the intersection.
questions.answerC: Where you think the stop line would be.
questions.answerD: With your front wheels in the crosswalk.
questions.explanation: At a stop sign, you must stop before the stop line, if there is one. If there is no stop line, you must stop before you enter the crosswalk. If there is neither a stop line nor a crosswalk, you must stop before you enter the intersection.

questions.question: A child passenger who is under the age of eight and less than ____ in height is required to be seated in an approved child safety seat while in a moving vehicle.
questions.answerB: 5 feet
questions.answerC: 4 feet, 11 inches
questions.explanation: New York law requires children who are under the age of eight and shorter than 4 feet, 9 inches tall, or weighing less than 100 pounds, to be seated in a government-approved child safety seat. They should not be allowed to use a seat belt until the seat belt fits properly.

questions.question: What does it mean when a school bus is stopped on a roadway and its red lights are flashing?
questions.answerA: You may pass if no children are on the road.
questions.answerB: You may not pass.
questions.answerC: You may pass if you are facing the front of the bus.
questions.answerD: You may pass if it is on the opposite side of a divided highway.
questions.explanation: When a stopped school bus is flashing its red lights, all traffic approaching the bus from any direction must stop at least 20 feet away from the bus. You may not resume driving until the red lights stop flashing or when the bus driver or a traffic officer signals that you can proceed. In New York State, you must stop for a school bus even if it is on the opposite side of a divided highway.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Low ground railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the overpass ahead has a low clearance. You should not proceed if your vehicle is taller than the height shown on the sign (in this case, 13 feet 6 inches).

questions.question: If you are driving on a highway next to a single broken white line marking:
questions.answerA: You cannot cross the line to pass.
questions.answerB: You may cross the line to pass and change lanes.
questions.answerC: You may only cross the line to change lanes if you are in the left lane.
questions.explanation: White lines separate lanes of traffic moving in the same direction. You may cross a dashed white line to pass or change lanes if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: A broken yellow centerline means that:
questions.answerB: Passing on the right is permitted when the way ahead is clear.
questions.answerC: Passing on the left is permitted when the way ahead is clear.
questions.explanation: A broken yellow centerline means that a driver may cross the centerline to pass another vehicle on the left as long as there is no oncoming traffic. Drivers should never cross a solid yellow centerline in order to pass.

questions.question: Seat belts are most effective when they are worn by:
questions.answerB: Passengers when they are on a long drive.
questions.answerC: All occupants of a car being driven on an expressway.
questions.answerD: All occupants of a car every time the car is driven.
questions.explanation: When you drive, make sure each person in your vehicle wears a seat belt. In the event of a crash, a person without a seat belt becomes a flying object and a danger to each person in the vehicle.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Watch for people crossing your path.
questions.answerB: No passing zone.
questions.answerC: Work zone ahead.
questions.explanation: This orange warning sign tells drivers that an area of roadwork is upcoming. When traveling through a work zone, stay alert for temporary traffic control devices.

questions.question: When driving under low-visibility conditions due to fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn on your high beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Slow down and use your low beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Increase your speed so you do not cause an accident.
questions.explanation: When driving in fog, you should slow down and use your low beam lights. If the fog is so dense that you cannot see, pull off the road and wait for the fog to clear.

questions.question: When you want to overtake and pass another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Wait for a signal from the other driver.
questions.answerB: Change lanes quickly so the other driver will see you.
questions.answerC: Signal and pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerD: Stay close behind the vehicle so you need less time to pass.
questions.explanation: If conditions are safe and legal for passing, check in your mirrors and signal your lane change. Before you pull into the left lane, look quickly over your left shoulder to make sure there is no vehicle in your blind spot.

questions.question: A flashing yellow light at an intersection means you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.answerB: Come to a complete stop as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Stop and proceed only when the intersection is clear.
questions.explanation: When encountering a flashing yellow light at an intersection, you should slow down and proceed with caution. You do not need to come to a complete stop when approaching a flashing yellow light.

questions.question: Speaking into or listening to a hand-held cell phone while driving:
questions.answerA: Is safer than using a hands-free cell phone.
questions.answerB: May only be done by teenage drivers.
questions.answerC: Is illegal.
questions.explanation: It is against the law in New York to speak into or listen to a hand-held cell phone while driving. You may use a hand-held phone to start or end a phone call, but further use will result in a fine and points against your license.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.answerC: Railroad ahead.
questions.explanation: A five-sided yellow or yellow-green sign alerts drivers to either a school zone or school crossing.

questions.question: On average, the human body can dispose of the alcohol in a 12-ounce beer in about:
questions.answerB: One day.
questions.answerC: Five minutes.
questions.explanation: On average, it takes the body about one hour to remove the alcohol content of 12 ounces of beer or wine coolers, 5 ounces of wine, or 1.5 ounces of hard liquor. In a 150-pound male, one of these drinks will raise the blood alcohol content (BAC) by about 0.02 percent. The removal of alcohol from the body may be slower in women, resulting in a higher BAC over a longer period of time.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: End of construction zone.
questions.answerC: School crossing ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a flagger ahead controlling traffic in a construction area.

questions.question: What is an important step in turning?
questions.answerB: Increase your speed.
questions.answerC: Always move to the left lane.
questions.explanation: When turning, you should look to the rear and both sides of your vehicle to ensure it is safe to proceed before making the turn. Adjust your speed to safely complete the turn.

questions.question: What message will be found on a red octagon-shaped sign?
questions.answerB: One-way.
questions.answerC: Stop.
questions.explanation: An octagonal (eight-sided) sign always means "stop." You must always come to a complete stop at this sign.

questions.question: In New York, a minimum blood alcohol content (BAC) of ____ is evidence of intoxication.
questions.answerB: 0.03 percent
questions.answerC: 0.1 percent
questions.explanation: Under New York State law, a BAC of 0.08 percent or higher is evidence of intoxication. A BAC of 0.05 percent or higher is legal evidence of impairment.

questions.question: A “No parking” sign at a certain location means:
questions.answerA: You may never stop your vehicle there.
questions.answerB: You may stop temporarily only to load or unload passengers.
questions.answerC: You may park there if the driver remains in the vehicle.
questions.answerD: You may leave your vehicle unattended for less than five minutes.
questions.explanation: A "No parking" sign means that you can make a temporary stop to load or discharge merchandise or passengers.

questions.question: Before switching on the ignition, you should:
questions.answerB: Be sure all passengers have buckled their safety belts.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: Develop a routine for entering and leaving your car. Before switching on the ignition, buckle your safety belt and see that all passengers do likewise.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: One-way traffic ahead.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that you must keep to the right of the upcoming divider.

questions.question: A motorist should know that a bicyclist operating on a roadway must:
questions.answerA: Ride on the right side of the road.
questions.answerB: Ride on the side of the road facing traffic.
questions.answerC: Ride on either side of the road.
questions.answerD: Ride on the side of the road with the least traffic.
questions.explanation: Bicyclists must ride in a bicycle lane, if one is available. If there is no bicycle lane, they must remain near the right curb or right edge of the road, moving in the same direction as traffic in the lane nearest them.

questions.question: When driving in rain, you must:
questions.answerB: Use high beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Use parking lights.
questions.explanation: In rainy conditions, you should use your low beam headlights.

questions.question: Only ____ can reduce blood alcohol content (BAC) and alcohol's effects on the body.
questions.answerB: Eating foods high in fat
questions.answerC: Time
questions.explanation: Only the passage of time can remove alcohol and its impairing effects from the body.

questions.question: When turning left at an intersection:
questions.answerA: You should always yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerB: Oncoming traffic and pedestrians should yield to you.
questions.answerC: You should never yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.explanation: Drivers making left turns must yield to oncoming traffic that is traveling straight. Drivers must always yield to pedestrians.

questions.question: If your car breaks down on a highway, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit in your car and wait for help.
questions.answerB: Use your four-way flashers to warn other drivers.
questions.answerC: Sound your horn at passing motorists.
questions.answerD: Flash your headlights at oncoming traffic.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on the highway, you should signal before carefully exiting the roadway and turning on your hazard flashers. Get as far off the road as possible and park in a location where other drivers can easily see you. Lift your hood to let other drivers know your vehicle is disabled.

questions.question: You must stop at a railroad crossing when:
questions.answerA: Directed to do so by a flagger.
questions.answerB: It is controlled by a stop sign.
questions.answerC: Flashing red signals and gates are present and operating.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger or stop sign. Stop when flashing red signals and gates are present and operating.

questions.question: Which of the following influence(s) the effects of alcohol?
questions.answerA: The amount of food in the stomach
questions.answerB: The body weight of an individual
questions.answerC: How much time passes between drinks
questions.explanation: Your blood alcohol content (BAC) depends on how much alcohol you drink, how much time passes between drinks, and your weight. Eating before or while you drink helps slow the absorption of alcohol somewhat, but it cannot prevent intoxication or impairment if you have too much to drink.

questions.question: If you are feeling fatigued while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed to reach your destination more quickly.
questions.answerB: Increase the volume of your radio.
questions.answerC: Find a safe parking area to take a short nap.
questions.explanation: When driving, watch for warning signs of fatigue. You are too tired to drive safely if you are struggling to keep your eyes open, drifting from your lane, or turning up the radio and rolling down your windows to keep yourself awake. If you notice these signs, it is a good idea to find a safe place to park so you can refresh yourself with a short nap.

questions.question: After stopping for a school bus that is unloading children:
questions.answerA: Do not proceed until the children wave to you.
questions.answerB: Watch for children walking along the side of the road.
questions.answerC: Accelerate quickly.
questions.explanation: After stopping for a school bus that has its stop arm extended and its lights flashing, watch for children walking along the side of the road. You should always drive with caution when driving near children.

questions.question: When meeting a car with blinding headlights, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your bright lights until the other vehicle dims theirs.
questions.answerB: Flash your lights on and off to warn the other driver.
questions.answerC: Dim your lights and then speed up to pass quickly.
questions.answerD: Look toward the right side of the road.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle comes toward you with its high beams on, look away from the headlights and toward the right side of the road until the car has passed. This will keep you from being blinded.

questions.question: When driving behind another vehicle under ideal driving conditions, you should follow the ____ rule.
questions.answerB: One-second
questions.answerC: Half-second
questions.explanation: Under ideal driving conditions, you should maintain a following distance of at least two seconds. If roads are slippery, your following distance should increase to at least three or four seconds. Any time conditions are less than perfect, you should increase your following distance.

questions.question: Before you leave a parking space that is parallel to the curb, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn on your four-way flashers.
questions.answerC: Look for traffic by turning your head.
questions.answerD: Look for traffic by using only your inside rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Before leaving a parking space to pull back into traffic, you should turn your head to look over your shoulder and check through the window for pedestrians, bicyclists, motorcyclists, and other vehicles that can become a hazard.

questions.question: The amount of space you need to cross traffic depends on the:
questions.answerA: Road conditions, weather conditions, and oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: Presence of a stop sign.
questions.answerC: Use of your turn signals.
questions.explanation: The amount of space you need to cross traffic depends on the road conditions, weather conditions, and oncoming traffic.

questions.question: If a tire suddenly blows out while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Grip the steering wheel firmly, slow down, and exit the traffic lane.
questions.answerB: Pump the brakes rapidly.
questions.answerC: Brake hard and steer toward the right edge of the roadway.
questions.explanation: If you experience a sudden tire blowout, do not panic. Grasp the steering wheel firmly and take your foot off the accelerator to allow the vehicle to roll to a stop. Lightly apply the breaks when it is safe to do so. Do not move to the shoulder of the road until the car has slowed considerably.

questions.question: You must not drive your vehicle at a speed greater than:
questions.answerB: A speed that is faster than is reasonable and prudent.
questions.answerC: A speed that is safe for existing conditions.
questions.explanation: You must not drive at a speed that is faster than is reasonable and prudent. You must drive at a speed that is appropriate for the area where you are driving, the type and condition of surrounding traffic, the presence of pedestrians, the weather, the quality of the road, and light conditions. You must drive within legal speed limits.

questions.question: A traffic light displaying a green arrow and a red light means that:
questions.answerA: You may only drive straight ahead.
questions.answerB: You may drive only in the direction of the green arrow.
questions.answerC: You must wait for a solid green light to proceed in any direction.
questions.answerD: Vehicles moving in any direction must stop.
questions.explanation: If a green arrow is shown with a red light, you can only drive in the direction of the arrow and only if the intersection is clear.

questions.question: Bicyclists differ from motorists in that they aren't required to:
questions.answerB: Signal all turns.
questions.answerC: Report accidents resulting in serious injury.
questions.explanation: Bicyclists are required to obey the same rules of the road as motor vehicle drivers. Any bicycle crash that causes death or serious injury must be reported to the DMV within 10 days of the incident.

questions.question: You are making a left turn from a two-way street onto a one-way street. When you have completed the turn, your car should be:
questions.answerA: In the right lane of the street.
questions.answerB: In the center of the street.
questions.answerC: In the left lane of the street.
questions.answerD: In the lane with the least traffic.
questions.explanation: If you are turning left from a two-way street onto a one-way street, you should complete the turn into the lane closest to the lane you have just left.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No left turn.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that left turns are prohibited.

questions.question: In general, you should pass vehicles that are traveling in the same direction as you:
questions.answerB: On their left.
questions.answerC: Only if the other driver signals that it is safe.
questions.answerD: Whenever you have the opportunity to do so.
questions.explanation: In general, the left lane is used for passing. Only pass when it is safe and legal to do so.

questions.question: A “No stopping” sign means that, unless directed to do so by a police officer, you may stop only:
questions.answerB: To avoid conflict with other traffic.
questions.answerC: To discharge passengers.
questions.explanation: A "No stopping" sign means you can only stop to obey a traffic signal, to obey a police officer, or to prevent a conflict with another vehicle.

questions.question: A driver who is taking a non-prescription drug should:
questions.answerA: Read the labels on the drug before driving.
questions.answerB: Drink alcohol instead.
questions.answerC: Continue to drive regardless of any warning labels.
questions.explanation: Many over-the-counter medications can affect your ability to drive safely. If you take medication, even a remedy for colds or allergies that is not prescribed, check the label for warnings about its effects. If you are unsure, ask your doctor or pharmacist about driving while on the medication.

questions.question: When you see a flashing yellow light at an intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Yield to all traffic before crossing the intersection.
questions.answerB: Stop, then enter the intersection when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Slow down and cross the intersection carefully.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light at an intersection indicates that drivers should slow to a safe and reasonable speed and proceed with caution.

questions.question: If traffic prevents you from crossing all the way across a set of railroad tracks, you may proceed only when:
questions.answerA: An approaching train is not moving fast enough to be a danger.
questions.answerB: There is room for your entire vehicle on the other side.
questions.answerC: At least one-half of your vehicle can cross the tracks.
questions.explanation: You must not, under any circumstances, attempt to cross railroad tracks unless you are certain that your entire vehicle will clear all of the tracks. If other traffic prevents you from going fully across, wait and cross only when there is room.

questions.question: On a green arrow, you must:
questions.answerA: Yield to any vehicle, bicycle, or pedestrian in the intersection.
questions.answerB: Yield to pedestrians only in the intersection.
questions.answerC: Wait four seconds before proceeding.
questions.explanation: A green arrow means "go." You must turn in the direction the arrow is pointing after you yield to any vehicles, bicycles, or pedestrians who are still in the intersection.

questions.question: This sign is used to prevent:
questions.answerB: Entrance to road construction areas.
questions.answerC: Entrance to dead-end streets.
questions.answerD: Entrances from the wrong direction on one-way streets and expressway ramps.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that a road has one-way traffic and you must not enter from your current direction.

questions.question: When driving behind another vehicle at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep your headlights on the low beam setting.
questions.answerB: Use your high beam headlights until you are within 10 feet of the vehicle ahead.
questions.answerC: Use your high beam headlights.
questions.explanation: Use high beam headlights only when driving in rural areas and when other cars are not nearby. Lower your headlights to their low beam setting when you are following closely behind another driver.

questions.question: In which of the following situations is passing always forbidden?
questions.answerA: The vehicle ahead is making a left turn.
questions.answerB: You are on a one-way street which has two lanes.
questions.answerC: The vehicle ahead is stopped for a pedestrian in a crosswalk.
questions.answerD: The vehicle ahead is going to park parallel to the curb.
questions.explanation: You must never pass a vehicle that has stopped at a crosswalk to allow a pedestrian to go across.

questions.question: A motorist approaching a bicyclist should:
questions.answerB: Proceed as usual.
questions.answerC: Swerve into the opposite lane.
questions.explanation: Drivers should reduce their speed as they pass bicyclists, as air movement from a passing vehicle can easily affect a bicyclist's balance.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Winding road ahead.
questions.answerC: Reserved parking for persons with disabilities.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that two lanes of traffic going the same direction will soon merge into one lane.

questions.question: If you have an argument with another person and you are angry, you should:
questions.answerA: Loudly play the radio while driving so you won’t think about your argument.
questions.answerB: Take a few minutes to cool off before driving.
questions.answerC: Drive on the interstate to let off steam.
questions.explanation: Your emotions affect your ability to drive safely. If you are overly angry, excited, afraid, worried, or depressed, you should give yourself time to calm down before operating a vehicle. You need to be able to mentally focus on driving without thinking about the things that made you upset.

questions.question: When approaching a steady yellow traffic light, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Accelerate to avoid a red light.
questions.answerB: Continue driving, as they have the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Slow to a stop, unless they are already within the intersection.
questions.answerD: Check to see what the cars next to them are doing.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow traffic light indicates that a red light is about to appear. Stop unless you are already within the intersection.

questions.question: If you are facing a green traffic light but the intersection ahead is blocked by traffic, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn left and find another route.
questions.answerB: Stay out of the intersection until traffic clears.
questions.answerC: Follow the other vehicles and enter the intersection.
questions.explanation: Even if you are facing a green traffic light, do not start across the intersection if there are other vehicles blocking your way. If you are caught in the intersection when the light changes to red, your vehicle will block cross traffic. You can get a ticket for blocking an intersection.

questions.question: When driving in fog, rain, or snow, use:
questions.answerB: High beams.
questions.answerC: Fog lights only.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights should be used in fog, rain, and snow. The light from high beams will reflect back to the driver under these weather conditions, causing a glare that will make it difficult to see ahead.

questions.question: On long trips, you can prevent drowsiness by:
questions.answerB: Slowing down.
questions.answerC: Stopping at regular intervals for a rest.
questions.answerD: Moving your eyes from side to side as you drive.
questions.explanation: To prevent drowsiness on long trips, you should schedule regular stops. Give yourself time to rest and stretch, even if you are not feeling tired.

questions.question: If you need to slow down while driving on a slippery road, the first thing you should do is:
questions.answerB: Take your foot off the gas pedal.
questions.answerC: Apply your parking brake.
questions.explanation: To slow down on a slippery road, you should first take your foot off the gas pedal. If you need to slow down even more, gently apply a slow, steady pressure to your brake pedal.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Keep right.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign means that right turns are prohibited.

questions.question: This white sign means you should not pass other vehicles:
questions.answerA: Until after you pass the sign.
questions.answerB: Unless it seems safe to do so.
questions.answerC: For any reason.
questions.explanation: A white rectangular sign indicates that you must obey the stated rule. This sign means that drivers should not pass other vehicles for any reason.

questions.question: This sign is a warning that you are approaching:
questions.answerB: A crosswalk.
questions.answerC: A railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: A round sign means you are approaching a railroad crossing. This sign is posted a few hundred feet in front of the tracks and tells drivers to slow down, look, listen, and prepare to stop.

questions.question: You hit a parked vehicle and can't find the owner. What must you do?
questions.answerA: Call your insurance company when you get home.
questions.answerB: Wait for the owner to return.
questions.answerC: Leave a note with your name and address on the parked vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you hit a parked vehicle or other property, you must leave a note with your name, phone number, and address securely attached to the vehicle or property that you hit.

questions.question: When passing on a multilane highway:
questions.answerA: Be sure the passing lane is clear.
questions.answerB: Pass only on the right.
questions.answerC: Watch for oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: There is no need to signal.
questions.explanation: Before passing, you must make sure the passing lane is clear and give the proper turn signal to show you are going to change lanes.

questions.question: A driver may park in a space reserved for people with disabilities if the vehicle displays the proper license plates:
questions.answerA: Regardless of who is in the vehicle.
questions.answerB: And only if the driver is disabled.
questions.answerC: And is carrying the disabled person named on the registration.
questions.answerD: And someone in the driver's immediate family is disabled.
questions.explanation: To park in a space reserved for people with disabilities, the vehicle must be in operation to transport the disabled person named on the registration or permit.

questions.question: There are two traffic lanes moving in your direction. You are driving in the left lane and many vehicles are passing you on the right. If the driver behind you wishes to drive faster, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in your lane so you don't impede the flow of traffic.
questions.answerB: Drive onto the left shoulder to let the other vehicles pass.
questions.answerC: Move into the right lane when it is safe.
questions.explanation: To drive quickly, pass, or turn left, use the left lane. Use the right lane when driving more slowly than surrounding traffic, entering the road, or turning right.

questions.question: To pass a slower-moving vehicle on a two-lane, two-way road, you must:
questions.answerB: Flash your lights at oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Use the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Use the lane that belongs to oncoming traffic.
questions.explanation: Passing on a two-lane, two-way road requires good judgment because you must use the lane belonging to oncoming traffic to complete your pass. Only pass if you may safely and legally do so.

questions.question: What does it mean when a school bus is stopped on a roadway and its red lights are flashing?
questions.answerA: You may pass if no children are on the road.
questions.answerB: You may not pass.
questions.answerC: You may pass if you are facing the front of the bus.
questions.answerD: You may pass if it is on the opposite side of a divided highway.
questions.explanation: When a stopped school bus is flashing its red lights, all traffic approaching the bus from any direction must stop at least 20 feet away from the bus. You may not resume driving until the red lights stop flashing or when the bus driver or a traffic officer signals that you can proceed. In New York State, you must stop for a school bus even if it is on the opposite side of a divided highway.

questions.question: As you near an intersection, the traffic light changes from green to yellow. Your best action is to:
questions.answerA: Speed up to beat the red light.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes sharply to stop.
questions.answerC: Be prepared to stop in the center of the intersection.
questions.answerD: Be prepared to stop before the intersection.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow traffic light indicates that the light will soon change to red. You should be prepared to stop for the red light, if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: If an approaching train is near enough or going fast enough to be a danger, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.answerB: Not cross the tracks until the train has completely passed.
questions.answerC: Cross the tracks at your own risk.
questions.answerD: Find an alternative route across tracks.
questions.explanation: You should look and listen for trains before crossing any railroad tracks. If an approaching train is near enough or going fast enough to be a danger, you cannot go across the tracks. This is true even if they have no signals or the signals are not working.

questions.question: Blind persons legally have the right-of-way when crossing the street when they are:
questions.answerB: Led by a guide dog or using a white or metallic cane.
questions.answerC: Helped by another person.
questions.explanation: Blind pedestrians who are being led by a guide dog or are using a white or metallic cane have the right-of-way at a marked or unmarked crosswalk, even if the traffic signals or other right-of-way rules are not in their favor.

questions.question: You are making a left turn from a two-way street onto a one-way street. When you have completed the turn, your car should be:
questions.answerA: In the right lane of the street.
questions.answerB: In the center of the street.
questions.answerC: In the left lane of the street.
questions.answerD: In the lane with the least traffic.
questions.explanation: If you are turning left from a two-way street onto a one-way street, you should complete the turn into the lane closest to the lane you have just left.

questions.question: This sign is used to prevent:
questions.answerB: Entrance to road construction areas.
questions.answerC: Entrance to dead-end streets.
questions.answerD: Entrances from the wrong direction on one-way streets and expressway ramps.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that a road has one-way traffic and you must not enter from your current direction.

questions.question: If your vehicle starts to lose traction because of water on the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Drive at a constant speed to gain better traction.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes firmly to prevent your vehicle from sliding.
questions.answerC: Slow down gradually and not apply the brakes.
questions.explanation: When driving in heavy rain at speeds as low as 30 mph, your tires may lose all contact with the road and instead ride up on a layer of water above the surface of the road. This is called "hydroplaning." If your vehicle starts to hydroplane, slow down gradually and do not apply the brakes.

questions.question: You may pass another vehicle on the right if it is waiting to:
questions.answerB: Turn left.
questions.answerC: Park at the curb.
questions.answerD: Turn into a driveway on the right.
questions.explanation: While you generally may pass only on the left, there are certain conditions under which passing on the right is permitted. You should only pass on the right if you can do so safely and you do not need to drive on or across the shoulder or edge line of the road. One situation where passing on the right is allowed is when the vehicle in front of you is making a left turn.

questions.question: Bicyclists differ from motorists in that they aren't required to:
questions.answerB: Signal all turns.
questions.answerC: Report accidents resulting in serious injury.
questions.explanation: Bicyclists are required to obey the same rules of the road as motor vehicle drivers. Any bicycle crash that causes death or serious injury must be reported to the DMV within 10 days of the incident.

questions.question: Assuming that the street is level, what should you do after you have finished parallel parking in a space between two other cars?
questions.answerA: Leave your front wheels turned toward the curb.
questions.answerB: Make sure your car almost touches the car behind you.
questions.answerC: Move as far forward in the space as possible.
questions.answerD: Straighten your front wheels and leave room between cars.
questions.explanation: The final step of parallel parking (unless you are on a hill) is to bring your wheels straight and pull forward, allowing room for surrounding vehicles to maneuver safely.

questions.question: You are driving on a one-way street. You may only turn left onto another one-way street if:
questions.answerA: You increase your speed before the turn.
questions.answerB: Traffic on the street moves to the right.
questions.answerC: Traffic on the street moves to the left.
questions.explanation: You may turn left onto a one-way street that moves to the left if there is no sign prohibiting the turn. You may not turn left onto a one-way street where traffic moves to the right.

questions.question: If your vehicle begins to skid, you should:
questions.answerA: Ease up on the gas pedal.
questions.answerB: Brake as hard as possible.
questions.answerC: Turn off the ignition.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to skid, release the accelerator or brake pedal to regain vehicle balance. Steer in the direction of the skid to regain control of the vehicle.

questions.question: Yellow lines separate:
questions.answerB: Traffic moving in opposite directions on two-way roads.
questions.answerC: All carpool lanes from regular traffic lanes.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines mark the center of a road used for two-way traffic. A solid yellow centerline indicates that drivers may not cross the line to pass. A broken yellow centerline indicates that drivers may cross the line to pass, but only if passing would not interfere with traffic.

questions.question: When parking uphill next to a curb, set the parking brake and:
questions.answerA: Keep the rear tires against the curb.
questions.answerB: Keep the front tires straight ahead.
questions.answerC: Turn your steering wheel away from the curb.
questions.answerD: Turn your steering wheel toward the curb.
questions.explanation: When parking facing uphill on a street that has a curb, set your parking brake and turn your steering wheel away from the curb. This way, if your vehicle starts to roll, it will roll into the curb.

questions.question: What does this road sign mean?
questions.answerA: Slow down and prepare to stop if cars are approaching you.
questions.answerB: Come to a full stop and go when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Proceed carefully through the intersection, not always stopping.
questions.answerD: Stop only for traffic on an intersecting road.
questions.explanation: A stop sign means that you must come to a full stop and yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians in or heading toward the intersection. Go again when it is safe.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: No U-turns.
questions.answerC: No exit.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that right turns are prohibited.

questions.question: Drinking alcohol and driving is:
questions.answerB: A serious traffic safety problem.
questions.answerC: Safe if you have only had a few drinks.
questions.answerD: Only dangerous to the driver who drinks.
questions.explanation: Driving while impaired or intoxicated is a serious traffic safety problem. Safe driving is not possible when you drink alcohol or take other drugs. Driving under the influence is dangerous both to you and to others on the road.

questions.question: If you see orange construction signs and cones on a freeway, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down because the lane ends ahead.
questions.answerB: Be prepared for workers and equipment ahead.
questions.answerC: Change lanes and maintain your current speed.
questions.explanation: As you enter a work zone, signs and message boards will warn you of workers, slow-moving equipment, and/or closed lanes ahead. You should reduce your speed and be prepared to slow down or stop.

questions.question: You are driving along a street and hear a siren. You cannot immediately see the emergency vehicle. You should:
questions.answerA: Keep driving until you see the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Pull to the curb and look to see if it is on your street.
questions.answerC: Slow down. Don't stop until you see it.
questions.answerD: Speed up and turn at the next intersection.
questions.explanation: If you hear a siren or an air horn close by but do not know exactly where the emergency vehicle is, safely pull over to the right side of the road and stop until you are sure it is not headed toward you.

questions.question: Minimum speed signs are designed to:
questions.answerB: Show current local road conditions.
questions.answerC: Test future traffic signal needs.
questions.explanation: To keep a smooth traffic flow, some highways have minimum speed limits. If you drive more slowly than the minimum speed limit, you can halt the traffic flow and create dangerous conditions. Even if there is no posted minimum speed limit, those driving too slowly can be dangerous and may receive a citation.

questions.question: The driver's left arm and hand are extended upward. This hand signal means that the driver plans to:
questions.answerB: Turn right.
questions.answerC: Come to a stop.
questions.explanation: If a driver's left arm and hand are extended upward, they are indicating that they intend to turn right. Adjust your driving accordingly if following a driver who is using this hand signal.

questions.question: Which of the following must you obey over the other three?
questions.answerB: A police officer
questions.answerC: A stop sign
questions.explanation: Directions given by traffic officers take precedence over signs, signals, and pavement markings. People authorized to direct traffic include police officers, fire police, highway work area flag persons, and school crossing persons.

questions.question: You drive defensively when you:
questions.answerA: Put one car length between you and the car ahead.
questions.answerB: Look only at the car in front of you while driving.
questions.answerC: Keep your eyes moving to look for possible hazards.
questions.explanation: You are driving defensively when you are looking down the road for potential hazards. Constantly staring at the road directly in front of your vehicle is dangerous. As you scan ahead, be alert to vehicles around you.

questions.question: There is no crosswalk and you see a pedestrian crossing your lane ahead. You should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with and then pass the pedestrian.
questions.answerB: Slow down as you pass the pedestrian.
questions.answerC: Stop and let the pedestrian finish crossing the street.
questions.explanation: At an intersection where traffic is not controlled by traffic signal lights, drivers are required to yield the right-of-way to pedestrians within any crosswalk, marked or unmarked. Even if there is no crosswalk, yield to the pedestrian.

questions.question: You may not cross a single broken white or yellow line:
questions.answerA: When doing so would interfere with traffic.
questions.answerB: When turning left into a driveway.
questions.answerC: When the car in front of you is disabled.
questions.answerD: When passing to the right on a one-way street.
questions.explanation: You may cross a single broken line to pass or change lanes as long as you can do so safely and without interfering with traffic.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: You must drive slowly and sound your horn.
questions.answerB: A bus stop is ahead.
questions.answerC: You are entering a school's parking lot.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are used to warn drivers about upcoming hazardous conditions and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers that they are approaching a school zone and that they should slow down and watch for children.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Merging traffic is approaching from the left.
questions.answerB: Winding road ahead.
questions.answerC: Right lane ends ahead, merge left.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the right lane ends ahead and drivers must merge left.

questions.question: If your vehicle has a two-part safety belt system, you should:
questions.answerB: Use both the lap and shoulder belts.
questions.answerC: Use only the shoulder belt.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has a two-part seat belt system, be sure to wear both the lap belt and the shoulder belt. Wearing either part alone greatly reduces your protection. If you have an automatic shoulder belt, be sure to buckle your lap belt as well.

questions.question: The car behind you begins to pass you. You should:
questions.answerA: Maintain your speed so traffic will flow smoothly.
questions.answerB: Pull to the right and stop so it can pass.
questions.answerC: Slow down slightly and stay in your lane.
questions.answerD: Blow your horn to signal that it to pass.
questions.explanation: If another vehicle passes you on the left, decrease your speed slightly and keep to the right. When the vehicle has safely passed and is ahead of you, resume your normal speed.

questions.question: You have the right-of-way when you are:
questions.answerB: Backing out of a driveway.
questions.answerC: Leaving a parking space.
questions.explanation: A driver who enters a traffic circle or rotary must yield the right-of-way to drivers already in the circle. Vehicles entering a roadway from a driveway must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and to vehicles already in the road. When leaving a parking space, you must yield to oncoming traffic.

questions.question: You want to turn right at the next intersection. You should begin to use your turn signal:
questions.answerA: At least 50 feet before the turn.
questions.answerB: When you reach the intersection.
questions.answerC: At least 100 feet before the turn.
questions.answerD: As soon as you see cars behind you.
questions.explanation: The law requires you to signal a turn or lane change with your mechanical turn signals or hand signals at least 100 feet in advance.

questions.question: You may never park:
questions.answerB: At the entrance of a building.
questions.answerC: In a crosswalk.
questions.answerD: Within 50 feet of a fire hydrant.
questions.explanation: It is illegal to park, stop, or stand within a crosswalk. Parking is prohibited within 15 feet of a fire hydrant.

questions.question: At dusk or on overcast days, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive using your parking lights.
questions.answerC: Not turn on any vehicle lights.
questions.explanation: At dusk or on overcast days, you must turn on your headlights. Dim your lights to their low beam setting when within 1,000 feet of an approaching vehicle and when within 500 feet of a vehicle that you are following. When driving in poor weather, always use your low beams.

questions.question: The maximum posted speed limit should be driven only:
questions.answerB: During the day.
questions.answerC: Under ideal conditions.
questions.explanation: The posted maximum speed limit is the fastest legal speed you can travel on a road under ideal conditions. It is safest to drive at the same speed as surrounding traffic, up to the maximum speed limit. Maintaining a safe speed at all times is a responsibility shared by all motorists.

questions.question: A solid yellow line on your side of the centerline means:
questions.answerB: Traffic light ahead.
questions.answerC: Do not pass.
questions.explanation: Solid yellow lines on two-lane roads indicate zones where passing is prohibited. If a solid yellow line appears next to a broken yellow line, drivers in the lane nearest to the solid yellow line may not pass. In some instances, both yellow lines will be solid, indicating that it is not safe to pass from either direction.

questions.question: You may park or stop along the shoulder of the freeway:
questions.answerA: As long as you turn on your four-way (emergency) flashers.
questions.answerB: If no part of your vehicle is on the road.
questions.answerC: If you need to look at a map for directions.
questions.answerD: Only if you have an emergency.
questions.explanation: It is prohibited to park on the shoulder of a freeway, except in an emergency.

questions.question: Distracted driving may be caused by:
questions.answerB: Talking or texting on a cellular phone.
questions.answerC: Changing a radio station or CD.
questions.explanation: It is estimated that drivers make 200 decisions for every mile traveled, making it vital that drivers focus their full attention on the task of driving. Performing any additional task can create a dangerous distraction.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Turn right at the intersection.
questions.answerC: Parking area ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of the presence of a crossroad ahead.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Side Road.
questions.answerC: Railroad Warning.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a stop sign is ahead.

questions.question: If traffic prevents you from crossing all the way across a set of railroad tracks, you may proceed only when:
questions.answerA: An approaching train is not moving fast enough to be a danger.
questions.answerB: There is room for your entire vehicle on the other side.
questions.answerC: At least one-half of your vehicle can cross the tracks.
questions.explanation: You must not, under any circumstances, attempt to cross railroad tracks unless you are certain that your entire vehicle will clear all of the tracks. If other traffic prevents you from going fully across, wait and cross only when there is room.

questions.question: After you have passed a car, you may return to the right lane when you:
questions.answerA: See the front bumper of the other car in your rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Have put your turn signal on.
questions.answerC: Have turned your headlights on.
questions.answerD: See the other car's headlights turn on.
questions.explanation: After passing on the left, before you return to the right lane, look at your interior rearview mirror and make sure you can see the front bumper of the passed vehicle. Look over your right shoulder to make sure you can see several feet of pavement between your vehicle and the one you passed. You may then return to the right lane.

questions.question: You want to back out of your driveway. You see children playing nearby. Before you start to move your car, you should:
questions.answerA: Rev your engine to warn the children that you are moving.
questions.answerB: Sound your horn so the children will hear you.
questions.answerC: Walk to the back of the car to be sure the way is clear.
questions.answerD: Tell the children to stay away from the driveway.
questions.explanation: When you back up a vehicle, look through your back window for pedestrians and other obstacles. Do not rely only on your mirrors, especially when children are near. Before you back into or out of a driveway, get out of the vehicle and check behind your vehicle.

questions.question: A motorist should know that a bicyclist operating on a roadway must:
questions.answerA: Ride on the right side of the road.
questions.answerB: Ride on the side of the road facing traffic.
questions.answerC: Ride on either side of the road.
questions.answerD: Ride on the side of the road with the least traffic.
questions.explanation: Bicyclists must ride in a bicycle lane, if one is available. If there is no bicycle lane, they must remain near the right curb or right edge of the road, moving in the same direction as traffic in the lane nearest them.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: You must stop ahead.
questions.answerC: Speeding is not allowed.
questions.answerD: There is a traffic signal ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a traffic signal ahead.

questions.question: A child passenger who is under the age of eight and less than ____ in height is required to be seated in an approved child safety seat while in a moving vehicle.
questions.answerB: 5 feet
questions.answerC: 4 feet, 11 inches
questions.explanation: New York law requires children who are under the age of eight and shorter than 4 feet, 9 inches tall, or weighing less than 100 pounds, to be seated in a government-approved child safety seat. They should not be allowed to use a seat belt until the seat belt fits properly.

questions.question: You are waiting in the intersection to complete a left turn. You should:
questions.answerA: Signal and keep your wheels turned to the left.
questions.answerB: Signal and keep your wheels straight.
questions.answerC: Flash your headlights so drivers will let you through.
questions.answerD: Drive around the rear of a car if it blocks you.
questions.explanation: You must always signal before turning or changing lanes. You should keep your wheels straight while waiting to make a left turn. If another vehicle hits you from behind, this ensures that you will not be pushed into oncoming traffic.

questions.question: When you see this road sign, you should:
questions.answerB: Keep left.
questions.answerC: Pass with caution.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign indicates that a divided highway is beginning and cars should keep to the right.

questions.question: Driving under the influence of any medication which impairs your driving is permitted:
questions.answerB: If you don't feel drowsy.
questions.answerC: If it is prescribed by a physician.
questions.explanation: It is illegal to drive under the influence of any substance that impairs your ability to drive safely. This includes alcohol, prescription medications, over-the-counter medications, and illegal drugs.

questions.question: When you see or hear an emergency vehicle coming, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop immediately and let the vehicle pass.
questions.answerB: Drive as far toward the right side of the road as is safe and stop.
questions.answerC: Proceed slowly and permit the vehicle to pass.
questions.answerD: Keep moving slowly, staying to the right side of the road.
questions.explanation: When driving on a two-lane roadway or undivided highway, you must yield to an emergency vehicle using its lights and/or siren, regardless of the direction from which it is approaching. Immediately drive as near as possible to the right side of the road and stop, taking care not to stop within an intersection.

questions.question: A flashing red traffic signal at an intersection has the same requirements as:
questions.answerB: A yield sign.
questions.answerC: A stop sign.
questions.explanation: When approaching a flashing red signal, you must stop and yield to all traffic that does not have to stop.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: A road joins from the right.
questions.answerC: The road ahead turns sharply right, then sharply left.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead turns sharply to the right and then sharply to the left.

questions.question: Traffic signals sometimes display arrows to control turns from specific lanes. A solid red arrow:
questions.answerA: Is never used as a traffic signal.
questions.answerB: Has the same meaning as a circular red traffic light.
questions.answerC: Means that drivers may turn in the direction indicated by the arrow.
questions.answerD: Means that the traffic the arrow is pointing toward must stop.
questions.explanation: A solid red arrow in a traffic signal means the same thing as a circular red traffic light. When an arrow is red, traffic in the indicated lane must stop and may not turn in the direction that the arrow is pointing.

questions.question: Interstate driving requires drivers to:
questions.answerA: Have the ability to safely drive at increased speeds.
questions.answerB: Be constantly alert.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: Safe use of the interstate demands drivers be constantly alert and capable of driving at high speeds.

questions.question: At night, it is hardest to see:
questions.answerB: Pedestrians.
questions.answerC: Other motorists.
questions.explanation: Compared to signs and other roadside objects, pedestrians are hardest to see at night.

questions.question: A solid yellow line on your side of the centerline means:
questions.answerB: Pass with caution.
questions.answerC: Do not pass.
questions.explanation: A solid yellow line next to your lane means that passing is not permitted from your direction.

questions.question: As you approach an intersection with a flashing yellow light:
questions.answerB: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.answerC: Wait for a green light before proceeding.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light means that you should slow down, check for cross traffic, and proceed with caution.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: You should stop for other traffic.
questions.answerB: Traffic is entering from another road and you should allow additional space for drivers to merge safely into the flow of traffic.
questions.answerC: Traffic is entering from another road and you should keep right.
questions.explanation: This sign alerts you to the possibility of traffic merging into the main stream of travel. After checking to your side and rear, you should move into another lane, if possible, to allow merging motorists a clear path.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Intersection ahead.
questions.answerC: Merging traffic from the right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is merging traffic entering from the right.

questions.question: If a motorist sees pedestrians in an upcoming crosswalk, what should the motorist do?
questions.answerA: Continue ahead. The motorist has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Wait for the pedestrians to cross the street.
questions.answerC: Pull to the right and go around the pedestrians.
questions.explanation: A driver must yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian within a crosswalk. The driver should wait until the intersection is clear to proceed.

questions.question: If you need to pass behind a tractor-trailer that is backing up, you should:
questions.answerB: Wait for the truck to stop backing up before you begin passing.
questions.answerC: Honk to let the driver know you are passing.
questions.answerD: Assume that the driver can see you.
questions.explanation: Large vehicles have large blind spots to the rear. If you are behind a large vehicle, it is very likely that the driver does not know you are there. Because of this, if you need to pass behind a large vehicle that is backing up, it is always the safest option to wait for the truck's backup maneuver to finish before you pass.

questions.question: When exiting an expressway, you should:
questions.answerB: Look at the posted speed limit for the road you are entering.
questions.answerC: Cut off other traffic.
questions.explanation: When exiting an expressway, it is important to be alert to other traffic moving nearby. Be sure to look at the new posted speed limit and check your speedometer. It is unlikely that you will be exiting onto a road with a speed limit as high as the one found on the expressway.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Steep grade ahead.
questions.answerC: Winding road.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign indicates that there is a steep hill ahead. Slow down and be ready to shift to a lower gear to control your speed and protect your brakes from damage.

questions.question: A motorist approaching a bicyclist should:
questions.answerB: Proceed as usual.
questions.answerC: Swerve into the opposite lane.
questions.explanation: Drivers should reduce their speed as they pass bicyclists, as air movement from a passing vehicle can easily affect a bicyclist's balance.

questions.question: A driver who is taking a non-prescription drug should:
questions.answerA: Read the labels on the drug before driving.
questions.answerB: Drink alcohol instead.
questions.answerC: Continue to drive regardless of any warning labels.
questions.explanation: Many over-the-counter medications can affect your ability to drive safely. If you take medication, even a remedy for colds or allergies that is not prescribed, check the label for warnings about its effects. If you are unsure, ask your doctor or pharmacist about driving while on the medication.

questions.question: What happens if you drink alcohol while taking prescription or over-the-counter medicine?
questions.answerA: The medicine reduces the effect of the alcohol.
questions.answerB: The alcohol will help the medicine cure a cold.
questions.answerC: The combination could multiply the effects of the alcohol or medicine.
questions.answerD: There is no effect because they are different substances.
questions.explanation: Consuming alcohol and other drugs together can increase the impairing effects of both. For example, having one drink while you are also using a cold remedy could affect you as much as several drinks would when being consumed separately from any medications.

questions.question: Which of these statements is true about drinking alcohol and driving?
questions.answerA: If you can walk in a straight line after drinking, it is safe to drive.
questions.answerB: If you are under the legal blood alcohol concentration limit, your driving isn't impaired.
questions.answerC: Alcohol affects judgement, which is needed to drive safely.
questions.explanation: Being under the influence of alcohol affects your judgment. Good judgement is necessary to react appropriately to things that you see or hear while on the road. Even if you are below the legal blood alcohol limit, consuming any amount of alcohol is likely to affect your ability to drive safely.

questions.question: You may cross a single solid white line on the highway:
questions.answerB: If traffic conditions require you to do so.
questions.answerC: Only to turn into a driveway.
questions.explanation: You may cross a single solid line to pass other vehicles or change lanes, but only if obstructions on the road or in traffic make the lane change necessary.

questions.question: When driving behind another vehicle under ideal driving conditions, you should follow the ____ rule.
questions.answerB: One-second
questions.answerC: Half-second
questions.explanation: Under ideal driving conditions, you should maintain a following distance of at least two seconds. If roads are slippery, your following distance should increase to at least three or four seconds. Any time conditions are less than perfect, you should increase your following distance.

questions.question: A traffic light displaying a green arrow and a red light means that:
questions.answerA: You may only drive straight ahead.
questions.answerB: You may drive only in the direction of the green arrow.
questions.answerC: You must wait for a solid green light to proceed in any direction.
questions.answerD: Vehicles moving in any direction must stop.
questions.explanation: If a green arrow is shown with a red light, you can only drive in the direction of the arrow and only if the intersection is clear.

questions.question: What should you do if your vehicle’s right wheels leave the pavement?
questions.answerB: Immediately pull all the way off of the road and get back on when it is safe.
questions.answerC: Accelerate and steer back on the road quickly.
questions.answerD: Take your foot off the accelerator, slow down, then ease back onto the road when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle’s right wheels leave the pavement, don't panic. Take your foot off the accelerator and steer parallel to the road. Slow down and ease back onto the roadway by keeping both hands on the steering wheel and steering into the road’s right lane with a small turn of the steering wheel. Check for traffic around you before steering back onto the pavement.

questions.question: You should be cautious when passing a bicycle because:
questions.answerA: You are moving faster than the bicycle.
questions.answerB: The bicycle always has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Oncoming traffic may not see you pull out to pass the bicycle.
questions.answerD: The cyclist may have to swerve into traffic to avoid an object on the road.
questions.explanation: You should always be cautious when passing a bicycle because the cyclist may have to swerve into traffic to avoid an object on the road. Always be particularly careful when driving near bicyclists.

questions.question: A “No standing” sign at a certain location means:
questions.answerA: You may never stop your vehicle there.
questions.answerB: You may park there if the driver remains in the vehicle.
questions.answerC: You may stop temporarily only to pickup or discharge passengers.
questions.answerD: You may stop to load or unload merchandise.
questions.explanation: A "No standing" sign means that you may only make a temporary stop to load or discharge passengers.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Intersection ahead.
questions.answerC: Hiking trails ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a school crossing is ahead.

questions.question: What is the appropriate action to take when approaching a railroad crossing that does not have signals to direct traffic?
questions.answerA: Always bring the car to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: Slow down and be prepared to stop.
questions.answerC: All railroad crossings have signals so you will never encounter this situation.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed to get across the tracks quickly.
questions.explanation: When approaching an unmarked railroad crossing, slow down and be prepared to stop. Before you cross, be sure that no trains are approaching from either direction on any track. If you see or hear a train coming, stop at a safe distance from the nearest track and wait to proceed until after the train passes.

questions.question: When approaching a traffic signal displaying a flashing yellow arrow, drivers:
questions.answerA: Should merge into a lane in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerB: Should come to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: May turn left after yielding to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerD: Have the right-of-way and may expect oncoming traffic to stop for them.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow arrow indicates that left turns are allowed in the direction of the arrow. However, the oncoming traffic has a green light and you must yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.

questions.question: You may drive around or under a gate that is being lowered or raised at a railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: As long as an approaching train is not too close.
questions.answerB: If your vehicle can do so without damaging the gate.
questions.answerC: If you first look carefully in both directions.
questions.explanation: Flashing red lights, lowered crossing gates, and/or bells at a railroad crossing mean that you must come to a complete stop. You must not go across the tracks until the lights and bells have stopped and the crossing gates are completely up. Do not drive around or under a gate that is moving up or down.

questions.question: While driving at night, a vehicle coming toward you has its high beams on, making it hard for you to see the road ahead. You should:
questions.answerA: Look ahead toward the left edge of your lane.
questions.answerB: Look ahead toward the right edge of your lane.
questions.answerC: Look straight ahead in your lane.
questions.explanation: If an oncoming driver fails to dim their high beams, you should avoid looking directly at the headlights. Instead, look toward the right edge of your lane and watch the oncoming vehicle out of the corner of your eye.

questions.question: What are the consequences of driving under the influence of alcohol or other drugs?
questions.answerB: A mandatory fine
questions.answerC: Driver license revocation
questions.explanation: Driving under the influence can be punished by a fine, jail sentence, and/or suspension or revocation of your license.

questions.question: A diamond-shaped sign means:
questions.answerB: Stop.
questions.answerC: Warning.
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped signs are used to warn drivers of special conditions or hazards ahead. They are typically yellow or orange in color.

questions.question: The driver's left arm and hand are extended downward. This hand signal means that the driver plans to:
questions.answerB: Turn right.
questions.answerC: Stop.
questions.explanation: If a driver's left arm and hand are extended downward, they are indicating that they intend to stop. Adjust your driving accordingly if following a driver who is using this hand signal.

questions.question: Seat belts are most effective when they are worn by:
questions.answerB: Passengers when they are on a long drive.
questions.answerC: All occupants of a car being driven on an expressway.
questions.answerD: All occupants of a car every time the car is driven.
questions.explanation: When you drive, make sure each person in your vehicle wears a seat belt. In the event of a crash, a person without a seat belt becomes a flying object and a danger to each person in the vehicle.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Do not enter.
questions.answerC: No turn on red.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a divided highway begins ahead. The road will split into two one-way roadways separated by a median or divider. You must keep to the right.

questions.question: If you’re going to turn left onto a one-way street, you should complete the turn into:
questions.answerB: The lane closest to your previous lane.
questions.answerC: Either lane.
questions.explanation: You should always turn from the lane that is closest to the direction you want to go. Turn into the lane closest to your previous lane.

questions.question: When the road is marked with a solid yellow line and a broken yellow line, with the broken line next to your lane, you may pass:
questions.answerB: If you are on an expressway.
questions.answerC: If traffic is clear.
questions.explanation: When there is a solid yellow line and a broken yellow line in the center of the road and the broken line is next to your lane, you may cross the lines to pass if there is no oncoming traffic.

questions.question: What might happen when alcohol is combined with another drug?
questions.answerA: The effects of the alcohol and the drug may both be increased.
questions.answerB: Nothing will happen.
questions.answerC: The effects of the alcohol and the drug may both be reduced.
questions.answerD: The effects of only the alcohol may be reduced.
